Total nonperforming assets declined 12% from the end of the third quarter, and there was a 45% decline in new nonperforming assets compared with the third quarter.As noted earlier, the rate of increase in criticized and classified loans is slowing. Early-stage delinquencies also improved. So as we've stated since January of last year, the area of most credit concern has been our commercial real estate portfolio and specifically, our exposures to Single-Family Homebuilders and our Retail segment. As we enter 2010, I think it's important that our investors know that as the result of the actions taken this past year, we have substantially addressed the Single-Family Homebuilders segment. This is not a major concern going forward.The portfolio management focused over the course of the year, combined with the reserved actions and dividing our commercial real estate portfolio into core and non-core segments, positions us better to deal with this exposure going forward. And Tim will provide details. Our C&I and consumer portfolios are experiencing higher than normal charge-offs given the weak economy, but we believe these will remain manageable with our consumer loan portfolio particularly performing better relative to peers.Now turning to Slide 9, despite a reduction due to the fourth quarter's loss, as expected our capital position remains a positive story. Our period end Tier 1 and total risk base capital ratios were 12.05% and 14.43%, respectively.  These are $2.6 billion and $1.9 billion above respective regulatory well-capitalized 6% and 10% thresholds. We continue to believe we have sufficient capital to weather a stressed economic scenario. I'll say it again, we continue to believe we have sufficient capital to weather a stressed economic scenario. Our tangible common equity ratio was 5.92%. A year ago at the end of 2008, we were at 4.04%. Liquidity, which has seen quarterly improvements for the first three quarters strengthened further. Again, this past quarter, a key driver was the strong 16% annualized growth rate in core deposits. Our loan-to-deposit ratio at the end of December was 91%, improved from 94% at the end of September and significantly improved from 108% at the end of 2008. Our deposit growth permitted us to reduce non-core funding by $1.8 billion during the quarter.Turning to governance and management, we continue to build the strength of our Board of Directors with the employment of Rick Neu [Neumeyer]. Rick was the former CFO and Treasurer of Charter One Financial and prior to that, he was in First Federal of Michigan. He's got extensive hands-on experience in Detroit and Cleveland markets and other markets, and he's a CPA by way of training. He's a tremendous addition to the board.Slide 10, a key element of growing Huntington is investing in resources and talent, especially in those areas that will grow revenue. The slides lists selected new management team members hired over the last several months. As you can see, some are in positions to take what we have and make it better like those in retail and business banking and commercial banking business segments. Other new hires are leaders and teams aimed at developing critical mass in existing businesses, such as currency risk management or to expand existing businesses into new markets like brokerage sales. And we've initiated a new business with the National Settlement's Team. These investments reflect the early stages of implementing our strategic plan. With that, I'd like to turn this over to Don for a financial performance review. Don?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. As noted on Slide 11, our net loss for the fourth quarter was $369.7 million or $0.56 a share. Two significant items impacted the quarter's result. First, we recognized a $73.6 million or $0.07 per share of gain from the redemption of subor
componenttext: Thanks, Steve. As noted on Slide 11, our net loss for the fourth quarter was $369.7 million or $0.56 a share. Two significant items impacted the quarter's result. First, we recognized a $73.6 million or $0.07 per share of gain from the redemption of subordinated notes. We completed a tender offer primarily in the fourth quarter, redeeming $371 million of our then outstanding subordinated debt. The gain represents the discount paid on the tender and the impact of closing out the related interests rate swap. Second, we had a $12 million or $0.02 per share of benefit from the recognition of certain previously deferred tax valuation allowances. Slide 12 provides a summary of our quarterly earnings trend. Many of the performance metrics will be discussed later in the presentation so let's move on. On Slide 13, we provided an overview of our pre-tax, pre-provisioned income performance. We believe this metric is useful in assessing the underlying operating performance. We calculate this metric by starting with the pre-tax earnings then excluding three items: provisions for credit losses, security gains and losses and amortization of intangibles. We also adjusted for a certain significant items including the gain resulting from this quarter's subordinated debt tender offer. On this basis, our pre-tax, pre-provisioned income for the third quarter was $242.1 million, up $4.9 million or 2% from the prior quarter. This improvement clearly reflected management actions taken during the year and we'll continue to look for additional opportunities to improve our core operating performance.Slide 14 provides a trend of our net interest income and our margin. During the fourth quarter, our fully taxed equivalent net interest income increased by $9.6 million, reflecting a one basis point decrease in our net interest margin and a $1.3 billion increase in our average earning asset base. The margin change [ph] (27:00) reflected a favorable impact of our improved deposit mix and loan pricing, offset by the negative impacts of our stronger liquidity position. The deposit growth resulting in increases to our investment security portfolio. Also impacting the margin was a swap in effectiveness occurring at the end of the third quarter, producing the current quarter's net interest income. On Slide 15, we show the change in the mix of our investment portfolio. With the growth in our deposits, we've invested the funds primarily in shorter duration and variable rate securities, such as agencies, agency CMO and certain asset-backed securities. The short-term nature of these investments provides a flexibility to reposition the portfolio if the yield curve starts to steepen, or if we decide to utilize the bond future loan growth.Continue on to Slide 16, we show the linked quarter of loan lease trend. Total commercial loans were down $0.8 billion or 4%, reflecting the impact of lower-lying utilization for our commercial borrowers. The decline also reflects the planned lower commercial real estate balances from the pay downs and charge-offs occurring during the quarter.  Total consumer loans were flat with the prior quarter, despite a 31% increase in the origination volume for automobile loans. This increased origination volume was offset by the impact of our continued run off of the auto leased portfolio and lower residential real estate balances. Turning to Slide 17, our strong core deposit growth continued into the fourth quarter. Total core deposits grew an annualized 16% rate, and the growth came from demand deposit and money market category. The Warren Bank acquisition added $260 million of core deposits an average. Even after adjusting for this impact, core deposits were up 13% on an annualized basis. Slide 18 shows the trends in our non-interest income category. Our non-interest income declined by $11.5 million from the prior quarter. Other income declined by $7.5 million, reflecting a $16.4 million lower benefit from the change in the fair value of our derivatives that did not qualify for hedge accounting. This was offset by $7.5 million of losses on loans held for sale in the third quarter.  Our service charges on deposit accounts declined $4.1 million from the third quarter levels, primarily due to lower NSF/OD-related fees.  Mortgage income was up $3.2 million, reflecting the stronger origination volume and a $2.2 million gain from the MSR hedging activity for the current quarter. The next slide is a summary of our expense trends. Total expenses were down $78.5 million from the prior quarter. This reduction was primarily due to the $73.6 million gain on the debt redemption. OREO and foreclosure expenses were down $20.4 million, as the prior quarter reflected a $14 million loss on one commercial OREO property. Personnel costs were up $8.5 million from the previous quarter. This increase included a $4.7 million increase from incentive-related costs. Core salaries were up about 2% from the third quarter, reflecting the increase of 81 FTE, primarily for specific strategic initiatives.Slide 20 is a summary of our capital trends. We completed a series of capital actions over the last year. The most recent action was the completion of a tender offer for our subordinated debt resulting in a $73.6 million of pre-tax gain. This transaction reflected the utilization of proceeds from our earlier common stock issuance. Our capital ratios throughout the year have improved, and with our TCE ratio increasing from 4.04% a year ago to 5.92% at the end of this year. Most importantly, we think these actions position as well to weather further economic challenges. We do not have any current plans to issue additional capital. Let me turn the presentation back over to Tim Barber for credit reviews.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Turning to Slide 21, our total net charge-offs were $88.8 million or 25% higher in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter, with substantial changes in the composition. Total commercial net charge-offs were $129.8 million higher in t
componenttext: Thanks, Don. Turning to Slide 21, our total net charge-offs were $88.8 million or 25% higher in the fourth quarter compared to the third quarter, with substantial changes in the composition. Total commercial net charge-offs were $129.8 million higher in the quarter as both the C&I and commercial real estate portfolio showed increases. In the consumer portfolio, there were no portfolio actions this quarter contributing to the significant decrease from the prior quarter. We saw elevated levels of losses as a result of the economic conditions. However, it is important to note that we continue to see a reduction in early-stage delinquencies despite the historically difficult fourth quarter time frame. As we consider our asset quality trends and drivers, the commercial real estate portfolio remains the most stressed and our primary concern. Within the commercial real estate portfolio, the Single-Family Homebuilders and the Retail projects remained the two highest risk segments, generating the bulk of the credit losses. Of the $258 million of commercial real estate charge-offs in the quarter, 73% were associated with these two segments. The retail portfolio alone comprised nearly 50% of the commercial real estate charge-offs. Both of these portfolio segments continued to show stress as we worked with the borrowers in resolving the credit issues.While historically, we have viewed the Single-Family Builder portfolio as the highest risk segment, we believe that we have substantially addressed that exposure at this point. Based on the sum total of our activity over the last two and a half years, we do not expect any material future credit impact from this portfolio segment. The $41 million increase in C&I net charge-offs was primarily associated with losses on four large C&I relationships. The four borrowers represent different industries but all were significantly impacted by the difficult economic environment over the past year.Aside from the impact of these loans, the quarter looked much the same as prior quarter. Given the difficult economic environment, we expect that there will be some continuing challenges in the C&I portfolio as we obtain and analyze updated financial information throughout the next year. But we feel comfortable regarding the overall performance of the C&I block. Of particular note is the continued strengthening of our business banking portfolio performance over the past couple of quarters. We continue to feel very good about the C&I loans in our Auto Finance and Dealer Services portfolio. We do not anticipate any material dealer-related losses in the portfolio even in the face of the market disruption over the past year. It has clearly been a positive for our portfolio. Our dealer selection criteria with the focus on multi-dealership groups has proven itself in this environment. While the outstandings have declined in this portfolio as the utilization on floor plan lines has decreased, we continue to pursue and win new relationships that meet our credit profile. In a seasonally difficult quarter, the consumer portfolio performed consistent with our expectations. The auto loans and leases continued their strong performance while the increased net charge-offs and home equity loans continue to be driven by our loss mitigation activities. There are fewer accounts in our loss mitigation queues today, as we continue to proactively work our way through the portfolio. Residential mortgages and the other consumer loan category were consistent with the prior quarter on an adjusted basis. In the residential portfolio, our loss from mitigation queues are down 50% from mid-year 2009. We were generally pleased with the results across our consumer portfolio during the quarter. There has been some industry discussion recently regarding the loss recognition on bankrupt accounts. We take an appropriately conservative stance on recognizing losses on customers who have filed for bankruptcy protection across the consumer portfolio. Slide 22 represents the net charge-off ratios associated with the portfolios. Turning to Slide 23, we were very pleased with the reduction in non-performing assets in the quarter. A $286 million or 12% reduction was centered in a substantially reduced inflow with significant payment and sales activity. The reduction was evident across all of the individual portfolios but was particularly strong in the commercial real estate portfolio. The accruing restructured loans shown at the bottom of the page reflect the impact of our continued efforts, particularly in the residential secured portfolio of segments. While the portfolio continued to be affected by the fragile economic environment across our footprint, our commitment to the enhanced portfolio management processes and problem loan resolution activity over the course of 2009 became more evident in this quarter.Slide 24 provides the reconciliation of the quarterly changes in the non-performing asset balances. You can see the dramatic decrease in the additions line from $900 million last quarter to under $500 million this quarter. Please note that we continue to be focused on the early recognition of non-accruals. As with the prior quarter, 35% of the total C&I and commercial real estate non-accrual loans were current from a payment standpoint.Auto loan losses represent the next largest reduction in the quarter. It is important to focus on the impact of each of the other line items. As you have heard us say over the last year, we have made a significant commitment to the size and expertise of our commercial workout group. Payments, return to accrual status and sales activities are all a function of this group's impact. Each of these line items represent a high watermark to date.As we view this slide, it is important to include some comments regarding the underlying migration we are seeing in the portfolio. Although non-accruing loans decreased by a net 12% in the quarter, we did see a continued increase in the level of criticized loans, although at less than a 4% range. This rate of increase is slightly lower than the third quarter results, one indication of some stabilization evident in the portfolio. As you may recall, in using Slide 68 in the appendix as a reference, there was a substantial migration of outstandings into the criticized category, a combination of the OLEM and classified segments in the second quarter, as a result of that quarter's broad-based review activity.The third and fourth quarter increases were manageable given the economic environment. The commercial real estate portfolio continues to be the primary source of the increases in criticized loan outstandings. We were encouraged by the low level of net change in criticized loan levels for both the C&I and business banking segments. This is consistent with our view that the commercial real estate portfolio is the primary driver of the asset quality performance.Slide 25 provides an overview of the asset quality trends, particularly in relation to our reserve levels. We have discussed the reduction in non-accruing loans and the basis for the increase in the charge-off ratio in the fourth quarter. The 90 plus days past due in accruing line represents a continued focus on asset portfolio management and non-accrual treatment decisions. Steve's provided an overview with a change in reserve levels for the quarter and the bottom half of this slide provides you with some historical context for the resulting ratios. Since we view the entire allowance for credit losses as available to cover loan losses, I will focus on the ACL ratios in my discussion.The 4.16% of outstandings and 80% coverage of non-accruing loans are in line with where we believe the industry will be as of the fourth quarter. The 96% coverage of adjusted non-accruing loans excludes the Franklin exposure. We have established to set of allowance for credit loss benchmarks to provide a basis of assessing the adequacy of the reserve. And it was within this framework that we determine the level of increase appropriate for the portfolio.In conjunction with our asset quality trends, the general economic conditions and a forward-looking view of the commercial real estate market, we use these benchmarks in determining the $450 million increase to the reserve. That with the $200 million increase in the judgmental component, including an enhancement to the economic reserve portion. There was also an incremental $200 million allocated primarily to the commercial real estate portfolio, addressing the severity of commercial real estate loss given default percentages and a longer-term view of the loss emergence time period. Lastly, approximately $50 million was a function of our normal annual process of adjusting the reserve factors on our consumer portfolios, allocated specifically to the residential and home equity portfolio of segments.We continue to be pleased with the steady reduction in the 30-day accruing delinquency ratio for the total commercial loan portfolio, as shown on Slide 26. This is a result of the focus and attention of our relationship managers and the enhanced portfolio management process we put into place over the course of the past 12 months. As expected, we had no accruing loans over 90 days past due.On Slide 27, our early-stage consumer delinquency trends are also positive, led by the significant reduction in the residential portfolio. This decrease represents a core decline as the portfolio of sale and timing of loss recognition adjustments in the third quarter did not impact this segment. The 90-plus days past due results were up slightly for the residential portfolio. It should be noted that the residential presentation excludes the government-guaranteed and Franklin-related loans. The auto and home equity portfolio has performed much as expected.The next four slides provide additional disclosure around our commercial real estate portfolio, specifically the reconciliation of the balance reductions and the introduction of the core versus non-core concept. You will be able to find the product type, the maturity schedules from the prior quarter on Slide 82 through 84 in the appendix.Slide 28 shows the material decrease in the level of commercial real estate outstandings since the year-ago quarter. While the net reduction of $2.4 billion is significant, an analysis of the specific component is important. We originated only $255 million of new commercial real estate credit, but did have over $1 billion of takedowns on existing projects. The remaining non-funded commitments associated with commercial real estate projects is not material. The $1.7 billion of payments is a very significant number and is a function of our commitment to reduce the commercial real estate concentration via portfolio of management activity, such rightsizing loans with our borrowers. The increased expertise in our commercial workout area and the ramp-up in payments over the course of the past two quarters reflect this commitment.As we have previously indicated, this past year we embarked on an exercise to properly classify our loans. In the first quarter, we made an initial series of changes, primarily centered on moving owner-occupied loans from commercial real estate to C&I based on the cash flow underwriting of the credits. We made similar adjustments in the fourth quarter, primarily associated with loans to healthcare entities and colleges and universities. We believe that loans underwritten based on cash flow from operations should be considered as commercial loans secured by real estate and not housed in the commercial real estate portfolio, which is a real estate project-oriented portfolio.The final portion of the reduction was associated with the charge-off activity. Slide 29 provides a summary of the credit quality metrics for the commercial real estate portfolio, including the breakout of the Single-Family Homebuilder and Retail project portfolio segments. Including the impact of the fourth quarter reserve build, we have taken a 31% grossed up credit mark on the remaining $857 million a single-family home builder portfolio. As I indicated earlier, we do not expect any material credit issues from the Homebuilder segment going forward. The retail portfolio has a 20% credit mark, which we also believe is an appropriate mark given our current assessment of the projects within the portfolio. The overall increase in the reserve level to 9.94% of loans represents a proactive assessment of the portfolio and the market dynamics likely to exist in the coming quarters.Slide 30 provides the basis for distinguishing between the core and non-core portions of our commercial real estate portfolio. The key to the core designation is the meaningful relationship, Midwest footprint projects and adequate returns on capital. This segregation gives our investors increased transparency as it allows us to provide ongoing performance metrics.Slide 31 provides the breakdown of the commercial real estate portfolio as of the end of the quarter with the September balances and credit metrics provided to facilitate comparisons. You can see the breakdown between the designations with core comprising 53% of the total. These borrowers we intend to support, grow and develop. While the core portfolio as of December is very clean, we have maintained a 4% reserve given the economic environment and commercial real estate market conditions. For the non-core portfolio, we have established very substantial reserves and calculated the credit mark. This 27% ratio indicates the aggregate credit mark incorporating both prior charge-offs and existing reserves associated with the loans in the portfolio. It does not include any full balance charge-offs or charge-offs taken on loans that have been paid off. The 27% mark includes a 40% factor on loans managed within the Special Assets division. We believe that this level of credit action puts us in a strong position of flexibility to continue to deal proactively with future credit issues. Let me turn the presentation back to Steve for wrap up.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jim. Turning to Slide 32, let me share with you my expectations about 2010's performance. First, we still do not believe there'll be any significant economic turnaround this year. We do see signs of stabilization and a key assumption for our cu
componenttext: Thank you, Jim. Turning to Slide 32, let me share with you my expectations about 2010's performance. First, we still do not believe there'll be any significant economic turnaround this year. We do see signs of stabilization and a key assumption for our current outlook comment is that the economy stabilizes at near the current level throughout the year. With that in mind, we expect net charge-offs and provision expense part will be meaningfully below 2009 levels. For us, 2009 is the peak year, our allowance for credit losses is expected to decline on an absolute basis from its year-end level, reflecting the utilization of existing reserves for elevated inherent losses. We expect our net interest margin will improve from the 3.19% level in the fourth quarter. We anticipate strong growth in core deposits as we grow our retail and business customer bases, as well as increase cross-sell performance to existing customers. Loan growth is expected to be flat to up slightly. From one hand, we expect increases in C&I and certain consumer segments as customer confidence improves. However, commercial real estate loans are expected to continue to decline. Fee income will continue to be flat and slightly down, however, we expect growth in asset management, as well as brokerage and insurance revenues offset in part by declines in NSF overdraft fees. Expenses are expected to increase, reflecting the investment of growth and implementation of key strategic initiatives. We believe these set of expectations will return us to quarterly profitable performance sometime during the year.Let me use the next slide to provide some perspective. On Slide 33, we showed that quarterly improvement in pre-tax, pre-provision performance. It also shows we're targeting the continued improvement $275 million in the third quarter. And this is an aggressive target, for sure, but one we feel is achievable, it will be dependent primarily on our ability to increase net interest income, control our expense growth by offsetting the cost of investments with improved efficiencies. The growth in net interest income is expected to reflect a combination of factors, including loan and investment securities growth. Continued growth in lower cost core deposits and the resulting improved funding mix and a higher net interest margin reflecting improved loan and deposit spreads.Let me use the next two slides to review key messages that I hope that come to our comments today. Throughout 2009, we reviewed all assets on the balance sheet. We specifically commented frequently about the in-depth review of our loan portfolios, as well as the strengthening of our credit management and review processes begun last January. These reviews are completed.Second, our loan loss reserves are strong and we're better positioned to continue to address the resolutions of problem credits. The rate of increase in criticized and classified loans, as well as the inflow into NPAs is slowing. Net charge-offs and provision expense reached their high watermark in 2009. The core and non-core segmentation of our commercial real estate portfolio provides greater transparency and facilitate its further reduction. This will result in an improved loan mix over time. We've made significant progress in addressing key commercial loan portfolio concerns, especially Franklin and the Single-Family Homebuilder segment of our commercial real estate portfolio. Our C&I and consumer loan portfolios continued to perform within expectations given the state of the economy. We continue to believe our consumer loan portfolio performance will outperform many of our peers on a relative basis. But I think its also important to remember that we're not yet out of this economic cycle. Negative credit migration is expected to continue though at a slower rate than we saw in 2009. On Slide 35 and continuing, our liquidity position has been built to very strong level, the strongest in many years. Our funding mix is much stronger and balance given the increase in core deposit. We're growing household and business relationships. Our capital is sufficient to weather a stressed economic scenario. We have no current plan to raise new capital. We're better positioned to eventually repay the $1.4 billion TARP capital.We're continuing to make progress in growing pre-tax, pre-provision earnings and our goal of $275 million by the third quarter is aggressive but we believe it's achievable. We're continuing to stress that our management team and the depth of expertise at all levels. We've shifted to offense as reflected in our new hirings and the implementation of our strategic plan. And we'll continue to make investments targeted to grow key fee businesses. We enjoyed one of the better fee income to revenue ratios amongst our regional peer banks. Lastly, when we put it all together, we believe we'll return a quarterly profitability during 2010.They said at the beginning, 2009 was a very difficult year. We're all excited about the possibilities for 2010. We still have credit challenges but we're much better prepared to deal with them today than a year ago. And I think those challenges, going forward, will be much more manageable. We're getting stronger every day at Huntington. So thank you for your interest. Operator, we'll now take questions. Courtney back to you.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your first question comes from the line of Dave Rochester from FBR Capital markets.
componenttext: Your first question comes from the line of Dave Rochester from FBR Capital markets.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the CRE portfolio, it sounds like you're very comfortable now with the write-downs on the single-family homebuilder portfolio. You're talking about continued stress in the CRE of a portion for 2010. Can you talk about the degree of
componenttext: My first question is on the CRE portfolio, it sounds like you're very comfortable now with the write-downs on the single-family homebuilder portfolio. You're talking about continued stress in the CRE of a portion for 2010. Can you talk about the degree of flexibility or cushion you factored into the reserve on this portfolio that's giving you comfort that the reserve builds are behind you? Does that 20% mark on the retail, basically, factor in further declines and values and increased frequency if we kind of bump along the bottom in stabilization?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think the credit mark is designed to convey exactly that. We have looked at the retail portfolio very, very closely. We take a forward-looking view of things such as rents, as an example and factor that into the values we use. And at the end of the day,
componenttext: I think the credit mark is designed to convey exactly that. We have looked at the retail portfolio very, very closely. We take a forward-looking view of things such as rents, as an example and factor that into the values we use. And at the end of the day, we believe we're comfortable or we have sufficiently address the issues at that 20% credit mark.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the reserve levels of sales you talked about on an absolute basis that declining. Should we see something like that occurring as early as the first quarter or is that more like a second half type of event?
componenttext: On the reserve levels of sales you talked about on an absolute basis that declining. Should we see something like that occurring as early as the first quarter or is that more like a second half type of event?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think second half. And to give you little more guidance, that decline is modest. We're not going to get the profitability off some significant reserve recapture, Dave. But we spent a lot of time throughout the year going through these portfolios. We
componenttext: No, I think second half. And to give you little more guidance, that decline is modest. We're not going to get the profitability off some significant reserve recapture, Dave. But we spent a lot of time throughout the year going through these portfolios. We spend a lot of time, particularly in the fourth quarter, looking at the trend and other information and projecting, I think as most people do, a continued soft commercial real estate market at '10. And we think we've gotten ourselves to a reasonable improvement level with the reserve build.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Patten from Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Bob Patten from Morgan Keegan.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sort of along the same lines, on the non-core CRE portfolio, we have a 27% mark. Now obviously, we're going to slowly try to exit this portfolio. You may have to induce bigger marks in order to get sales done or to get deals done. How did you come to the
componenttext: Sort of along the same lines, on the non-core CRE portfolio, we have a 27% mark. Now obviously, we're going to slowly try to exit this portfolio. You may have to induce bigger marks in order to get sales done or to get deals done. How did you come to the 27% number?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The 27% is an aggregation of the entire portfolio. So there is a portion of that, that 40 plus percent credit mark. There's a portion of that that's below 27%. I think its important to talk a little bit about what's in there, within the non-core is a sign
componenttext: The 27% is an aggregation of the entire portfolio. So there is a portion of that, that 40 plus percent credit mark. There's a portion of that that's below 27%. I think its important to talk a little bit about what's in there, within the non-core is a significant amount of what we call investment real estate loans that tend to be smaller, commercial loan. It doesn't mean they're core performers, it just means that's not a business that were going to engage in going forward. So there's a real mix in that portfolio. And from an aggregate level, the 27% makes a lot of sense to us incorporating what we see today, as well as what we think is going to happen in the coming months.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: There was a tremendous effort in scrubbing this book to break at core, non-core and a lot of sensitivity analysis. So we've got a lot of confidence around the core, these are identified customers. Randy, why don't you just comment briefly about that, if y
componenttext: There was a tremendous effort in scrubbing this book to break at core, non-core and a lot of sensitivity analysis. So we've got a lot of confidence around the core, these are identified customers. Randy, why don't you just comment briefly about that, if you would, so you'll get a sense of how we're viewing this.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And as you can imagine, I've got a passion about this. We use the core and non-core development with an ongoing process that not only engage the business segment but included a credit administration risks and policy. We look at the core portfolio just to
componenttext: And as you can imagine, I've got a passion about this. We use the core and non-core development with an ongoing process that not only engage the business segment but included a credit administration risks and policy. We look at the core portfolio just to give you some metrics of that. On average, they've been customers of this bank for well over a decade, they have nearly 30 years in the business. However, we address some of the sensitivity issues that Steve mentioned, we look at this portfolio on a performing basis and uses 7%, 25-year amortization on average portfolio has over 130 debt service to cover. We have on each and every borrower, global cash flows on their business. We actually have verified the cash of the guarantor, 95 plus percent of this book does have guarantors. We have operating level cash flows. And even with this, what we believe to be a good portfolio of commercial real estate, we have an ongoing review process that we look at a portion, if not all of these loans, on a rolling monthly basis. So we have an ongoing prudent process to be sure that we are identifying in the early stage if any risks that may be in the portfolio. So it was a rigorous process that brought us to these conclusions, and we're very comfortable with where we sit today.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I would say, last year, we were almost at the firehouse stage for much of the year, absorbing. And I think many of you use to catch the falling knife analogy. We've caught it, we've got a tight grip on it. A consequence of that is our mentality is shi
componenttext: And I would say, last year, we were almost at the firehouse stage for much of the year, absorbing. And I think many of you use to catch the falling knife analogy. We've caught it, we've got a tight grip on it. A consequence of that is our mentality is shifting into a value maximization out of what might be thought of as a triage and maybe even a bit of a dumping approach.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Matthew O'Connor from Deutsche Bank.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: If I could follow-up on the positive net interest margin outlook, looking at the liability side of things, it seems like there's still a lot of room to reprice your core CDs. I think they're causing you north of 3% and there's still some higher cost broke
componenttext: If I could follow-up on the positive net interest margin outlook, looking at the liability side of things, it seems like there's still a lot of room to reprice your core CDs. I think they're causing you north of 3% and there's still some higher cost brokered CDs that you seem to be running off. So I'm just wondering given from the flexibility over time, on the liability side, can you give us a sense of the magnitude of the margin expansion that you're expecting here?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the margin expansion, I think that we will see the benefit of that deposit book repricing that our average going on rate for time deposit is right around 1%, there clearly is a lift coming from that. I think our greater opportunity as far as the
componenttext: As far as the margin expansion, I think that we will see the benefit of that deposit book repricing that our average going on rate for time deposit is right around 1%, there clearly is a lift coming from that. I think our greater opportunity as far as the deposit bases continue to see the positive mix change that we're generating here. As you've noted, that our time deposit balances are going down. We're seeing very strong growth in the core transaction accounts. And we've been underweighted in that historically compared to what we think the industry is performing at. So that clearly we'll add additional margin of benefit for us. And historically, we've talked about that being up where 20 to 25 basis points just for the lift from the deposit mix change, and I think that kind of gives you a ballpark range.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just separately, the inflows into non-performer were down sharply quarter-to-quarter. Do you think this level is sustainable or could it tick up a little? I guess, was there anything unusual that made the number so low or?
componenttext: And then just separately, the inflows into non-performer were down sharply quarter-to-quarter. Do you think this level is sustainable or could it tick up a little? I guess, was there anything unusual that made the number so low or?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Matt, in the third quarter, we tried to really proactively identify what we saw possibly emerging, and we think we did that. That contributed in part, maybe a large part to the fourth quarter slowdown. But we don't see that as a one quarter pheno
componenttext: I think, Matt, in the third quarter, we tried to really proactively identify what we saw possibly emerging, and we think we did that. That contributed in part, maybe a large part to the fourth quarter slowdown. But we don't see that as a one quarter phenomenon. Our early on view of the first quarter is encouraging in that and in other respects.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Matt, I would add that we didn't change the focus on early identification, 35% of them are still current. 50% of them are less than 90 days past due. So the decrease was not a function of a change in treatment in any way.
componenttext: Matt, I would add that we didn't change the focus on early identification, 35% of them are still current. 50% of them are less than 90 days past due. So the decrease was not a function of a change in treatment in any way.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And the bulk of the reduction again was cash payment. Fundamentally, it reflects our efforts to direct activity and resolution of credit.
componenttext: And the bulk of the reduction again was cash payment. Fundamentally, it reflects our efforts to direct activity and resolution of credit.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran from Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Brian Foran from Goldman Sachs.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: A lot of banks were putting excess liquidity to work over the past three or five months, did you kind of walk through why you were carrying the excess liquidity?
componenttext: A lot of banks were putting excess liquidity to work over the past three or five months, did you kind of walk through why you were carrying the excess liquidity?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've continued to carry the excess liquidity just because of deposit growth we've experienced throughout the last quarter. Our core deposits were up $1.3 billion from the third quarter to fourth quarter. And that's resulted in a net increase to our earni
componenttext: We've continued to carry the excess liquidity just because of deposit growth we've experienced throughout the last quarter. Our core deposits were up $1.3 billion from the third quarter to fourth quarter. And that's resulted in a net increase to our earning and asset base. And so we think that's a distinguishing factor compared to some of our competitors, is that with their shrinking balance sheet, they probably showed a wider expansion in their margin. If we would have just kept our balance sheet flat and not have that deposit growth, our margin instead of the 319 would have been at 326. We think its prudent for us to continue to focus on growing those core deposit relationships and continue to focus on that going forward.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We shared earlier strategically that we wanted -- we believe we take the balance sheet into a deposit funded balance sheet. And we're making progress in that regard with core deposits.
componenttext: We shared earlier strategically that we wanted -- we believe we take the balance sheet into a deposit funded balance sheet. And we're making progress in that regard with core deposits.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And if could follow-up, you kind of touched on it, but if I translate that just on the excess liquidity point, the margin point you're making to net interest income dollars. Are you going to be rolling off kind of limited spread securities and therefore m
componenttext: And if could follow-up, you kind of touched on it, but if I translate that just on the excess liquidity point, the margin point you're making to net interest income dollars. Are you going to be rolling off kind of limited spread securities and therefore margin goes up but all else equal net interest income isn't really affected or is this a case where you're going to be taking excess liquidity and remixing it into higher yield loans or securities?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: One, we think the net interest income will continue to improve over the next several quarters. And we think that could be a key driver for us to get to the $275 million of pre-tax, pre-provision level. I think that we're trying to position the balance she
componenttext: One, we think the net interest income will continue to improve over the next several quarters. And we think that could be a key driver for us to get to the $275 million of pre-tax, pre-provision level. I think that we're trying to position the balance sheet in such a way that right now, so that we're investing the proceeds from our deposit growth and fairly short dated or variable rate security, so that as rate do start to tick up, we're better positioned to be able to leverage that increasing rate. We got a thing that we do have available at some point in time. We are going to start to see that the loan side of the balance sheet start to pick up again. We saw a little bit of that of with the indirect auto, our pipeline's very strong on the commercial and the C&I book. And so we think that will also provide incremental lift compared to what we're seeing now, as far as a 230 type of investment yield on new asset purchases there.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The shift in the asset mix as you questioned, is one of the bigger opportunities for us. We're very, very liquid.
componenttext: The shift in the asset mix as you questioned, is one of the bigger opportunities for us. We're very, very liquid.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Siefers from Sandler O'Neill.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Scott Siefers from Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on the guidance, you gave a lot of good detail on the expense expectations, for example. I guess I was a bit surprised that almost all of the guidance for the higher pre-provision earnings comes from the revenue side and there's no real expectation f
componenttext: Just on the guidance, you gave a lot of good detail on the expense expectations, for example. I guess I was a bit surprised that almost all of the guidance for the higher pre-provision earnings comes from the revenue side and there's no real expectation for lower expenses. I guess I'm just curious what type of flexibility or contingency plans you guys would have on the cost side just to help you meet the pre-provision earnings goal, if the revenue side doesn't standout as anticipated?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your question would reflect the answer. If we're not getting the revenue, we'll dial back the expenses. But the expense build reflects an intent to invest on a multi-year basis to deliver a strategic plan that has a number of different growth dimensions a
componenttext: Your question would reflect the answer. If we're not getting the revenue, we'll dial back the expenses. But the expense build reflects an intent to invest on a multi-year basis to deliver a strategic plan that has a number of different growth dimensions and has a ramp-up that doesn't entirely come through in our outlook for 2010. If we need to adjust it, we will Scott.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was hoping you could just explain specifically, again, what exactly changed with the reserving methodology? Really, I'm just trying to understand what was it about fourth quarter that you were not doing in third quarter? Did you see any incremental dete
componenttext: I was hoping you could just explain specifically, again, what exactly changed with the reserving methodology? Really, I'm just trying to understand what was it about fourth quarter that you were not doing in third quarter? Did you see any incremental deterioration? And really, I'm just trying to get at, if you go through this sort of annual reviews, are we going to see another big reserve build at some point in the future?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We went through, what I would call, our annual review of the process. I think that was clearly colored this quarter by the market and in particular, the commercial real estate market, how we are thinking about it. We also were faced with thinking about ch
componenttext: We went through, what I would call, our annual review of the process. I think that was clearly colored this quarter by the market and in particular, the commercial real estate market, how we are thinking about it. We also were faced with thinking about changes in our asset quality conditions, while non-performers were down $500 million of inflow is a significant number. Our criticized loan levels continue to increase albeit at a slower rate. So as we thought about all of those factors combined, we felt that it was prudent to increase the reserve. I've provided a breakdown in the comments and I'm happy to go back through that if you like. A fair amount of it had to do with commercial real estate. Both in terms of the severity side of the equation, as well as the time frame over which we're seeing losses. We also incorporated a more substantial judgmental portion to the reserve, specifically enhanced our economic reserve modeling portion of that. And then the last piece was what I would call a normal or very regular change in our consumer reserve factor that's something that we have been doing for well over five years now. And there have been both positive and negative moves over the course of that five-year period.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And is there any explicit assumptions about you would need to see, basically, you'd have to hit your guidance of lower NPLs or reduction in classifieds in order to make sure that the reserve is adequate? Or if you see sort of ongoing NPL inflows at reduce
componenttext: And is there any explicit assumptions about you would need to see, basically, you'd have to hit your guidance of lower NPLs or reduction in classifieds in order to make sure that the reserve is adequate? Or if you see sort of ongoing NPL inflows at reduced levels but still elevated levels that, that would require additional reserve build?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've got a series of benchmarks that we've put together that provides an overall view of the adequacy going forward. Certainly, changes in non-accruing loans is one of those, but it is not the only one. As you mentioned the quality, if I can use that ter
componenttext: We've got a series of benchmarks that we've put together that provides an overall view of the adequacy going forward. Certainly, changes in non-accruing loans is one of those, but it is not the only one. As you mentioned the quality, if I can use that term in conjunction with non-accruing loans, we'd have a significant impact on how we think about reserve level going forward.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: As a consequence of the review activity monthly, there's a shared conclusion that we have turned the corner, we have expectations of improvement. And to be prudent about potential material or ongoing degradation, we're suggesting that reserve recaptor wou
componenttext: As a consequence of the review activity monthly, there's a shared conclusion that we have turned the corner, we have expectations of improvement. And to be prudent about potential material or ongoing degradation, we're suggesting that reserve recaptor would be modest in the course of '10 even though our expectation is that we'll be able to demonstrate meaningful improvement throughout the year.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Penala from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Penala from UBS.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you come through your commercial real estate portfolio and stress tested it, did you stress test that service coverage ratios for higher interest rates?
componenttext: When you come through your commercial real estate portfolio and stress tested it, did you stress test that service coverage ratios for higher interest rates?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we used a 7% fixed.
componenttext: Yes, we used a 7% fixed.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sorry, could you explain that?
componenttext: Sorry, could you explain that?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we looked at was from a permanent market, if it did exist today we felt that a normalized rate would be at a 7% constant. So we did that with a 25 year and [ph] which would take your constant into the low 8%. And with that, it would have about 130 de
componenttext: What we looked at was from a permanent market, if it did exist today we felt that a normalized rate would be at a 7% constant. So we did that with a 25 year and [ph] which would take your constant into the low 8%. And with that, it would have about 130 debt service cover. Whenever we would look at the contractual rate, which if we reflect back to 12, 24 months, whenever it was a very aggressive pricing market and these loans were based upon LIBOR, maybe a spread as low as 200 over LIBOR. That  contractual rate, the actual debt service cover goes up into the 140, so the note rate that they're paying us has a better coverage than what we would have used with the 7%. So we raised it to the 7% to give some cushion to know if we had the ability to take the loan out. So that was kind of the margin. And even with the 7%, we still feel that we have adequate debt service cover with that 1.3.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I know its hard to generalize given the different asset classes within the portfolio. But the 1.3 debt service coverage, what does that assume in terms of forward rents?
componenttext: And I know its hard to generalize given the different asset classes within the portfolio. But the 1.3 debt service coverage, what does that assume in terms of forward rents?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: What we would do -- we always are constantly reappraising as required and we will use those appraisals and look at the rents. And as we look at it going forward, the rents that we're seeing are downward. There's no doubt about that. So as we model those a
componenttext: What we would do -- we always are constantly reappraising as required and we will use those appraisals and look at the rents. And as we look at it going forward, the rents that we're seeing are downward. There's no doubt about that. So as we model those as we go forward, and we put together the pro forma cash flow we generally take those rents down.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And just a quick question, following up with Matt's question, on the margin guidance, what are you assuming in terms of the underlying interest rate environment?
componenttext: And just a quick question, following up with Matt's question, on the margin guidance, what are you assuming in terms of the underlying interest rate environment?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our base underlying assumption includes the forward curve. And so it assumes, basically, a short in the curve, stays really flat until the end of the year. I think it was about 25 basis points increase in the third or fourth quarter. But we're not assumin
componenttext: Our base underlying assumption includes the forward curve. And so it assumes, basically, a short in the curve, stays really flat until the end of the year. I think it was about 25 basis points increase in the third or fourth quarter. But we're not assuming any, essentially, any significant lift coming from that, where we tend to manage our interest rate risk position as mutually, as we possibly can.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin from Bank of America.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question on capital, Steve, hearing your comments that you feel really good about where your capital levels are to withstand any type of adverse scenarios, I'm just wondering can you give us some understanding of kind of where your expect capital
componenttext: Just one question on capital, Steve, hearing your comments that you feel really good about where your capital levels are to withstand any type of adverse scenarios, I'm just wondering can you give us some understanding of kind of where your expect capital to live? What you're going to be managing to, over the longer term?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: One of the -- first of all, we're comfortable with where we are. We're expecting at some point there's going to be some regulatory guidance that emerges in '10. We think we're prudent with where we are and we expect to, in turning to profitability, to be
componenttext: One of the -- first of all, we're comfortable with where we are. We're expecting at some point there's going to be some regulatory guidance that emerges in '10. We think we're prudent with where we are and we expect to, in turning to profitability, to be generating capital. So that's the basis for the current position.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So we just have to wait and see on what the real ratios are before you can actually set a...
componenttext: So we just have to wait and see on what the real ratios are before you can actually set a...

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We can, but we don't think we're going to be -- we're not convinced we'd be outside of any ranges to begin with. And we certainly know what to expect to be meaningfully outside.
componenttext: We can, but we don't think we're going to be -- we're not convinced we'd be outside of any ranges to begin with. And we certainly know what to expect to be meaningfully outside.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: With regards to the DTA, as you get to that point where you do expect profitability, what needs to occur to be able to recapture the rest of portion of the DTA that's currently excluded from your regulatory ratios?
componenttext: With regards to the DTA, as you get to that point where you do expect profitability, what needs to occur to be able to recapture the rest of portion of the DTA that's currently excluded from your regulatory ratios?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The regulatory calculation can get a little complex but essentially it will take about our fourth quarter process before you start to see some of that benefit return. But it's really utilization of the reserves that are established. It could create some o
componenttext: The regulatory calculation can get a little complex but essentially it will take about our fourth quarter process before you start to see some of that benefit return. But it's really utilization of the reserves that are established. It could create some of the reduction that DTA just allowed.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So that was the way [ph]?
componenttext: So that was the way [ph]?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your final question comes from the line of Jeff Davis at FTN Capital.
componenttext: Your final question comes from the line of Jeff Davis at FTN Capital.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, the FDIC presumably is going to ramp up closures in Michigan, I know you've done one deal up there, what's your interest in expanding your footprint in depository base up there? In the FDIC?
componenttext: Steve, the FDIC presumably is going to ramp up closures in Michigan, I know you've done one deal up there, what's your interest in expanding your footprint in depository base up there? In the FDIC?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, as we've said before, we will opportunistically look at acquiring the transactions and possibly a variety of flavors. But it's really important to us. Our primary focus is getting to profitability, executing our strategic plan, driving the core. We'
componenttext: Jeff, as we've said before, we will opportunistically look at acquiring the transactions and possibly a variety of flavors. But it's really important to us. Our primary focus is getting to profitability, executing our strategic plan, driving the core. We're not feeling any pressure to do another little deal in Michigan or for that matter anywhere else. And there is a distraction factor doing these little things. I don't mean to be demeaning in terms of -- to any acquisitions.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Everybody, this is Jay Gould. I apologize for the couple of people that were still in the queue. If you have those questions please bring to my attention and I'll sit down with you, or Don, or whoever we need to get together. But we have another time comm
componenttext: Everybody, this is Jay Gould. I apologize for the couple of people that were still in the queue. If you have those questions please bring to my attention and I'll sit down with you, or Don, or whoever we need to get together. But we have another time commitment coming right upon us. So thanks for participating. We appreciate your interest in Huntington. And we'll talk to you later. Goodbye.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Jan 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.
componenttext: This concludes today's conference call. You may now disconnect.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good morning. My name is Jeff and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Huntington first quarter earnings call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speaker
componenttext:
Good morning. My name is Jeff and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Huntington first quarter earnings call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers' remarks, there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator Instructions). Thank you.
Mr. Gould, you may begin your conference.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jeff and welcome. I'm Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides we will be reviewing could be found on our website, huntington.com. This call is being recorded and will be available as a rebroadcast starting
componenttext:
Thank you, Jeff and welcome. I'm Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides we will be reviewing could be found on our website, huntington.com. This call is being recorded and will be available as a rebroadcast starting about one hour from the close of the call.
Please call Investor Relations at 614-480-5676 for more information on how to access these recordings or playback or should you have difficulty getting a copy of the slides.
Turning to slides two, three and four, you will note several aspects of the basis of todays presentation. I encourage you to read these, but let me point out one key disclosure.
This presentation contains both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures, where we believe it is helpful to understanding Huntingtons results of operations or financial position. Where non-GAAP financial measures are used, the comparable GAAP financial measure, as well as the reconciliation to the comparable GAAP financial measure, can be found on the slide presentation, in as appendix, in the press release, in the quarterly financial review supplement to todays earnings press release or in the related 8-K filed today, all of which are on our website.
Turning to slide five, todays discussion including the Q&A period may contain forward-looking statements. Such statements are based on information and assumptions available at this time and are subject to changes, risks and uncertainties, which may cause actual results to differ materially. We assume no obligation to update such statements.
For a complete discussion of risks and uncertainties, please refer to this slide and material information filed with the SEC including our most recent Forms 10-K and 8-K filings. 
Now, turning to todays presentation. As noted on slide six, participating today are Steve Steinour, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Don Kimble, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Tim Barber, Senior Vice President of Credit Risk Management. Also present for the Q&A session is Dan Neumeyer, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Credit Officer.
Lets get going. Turning to slide seven, Steve?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Jay. Welcome everyone. I will begin with review of our first quarter performance highlights, Don will follow with the detailed overview of our financial performance, Tim will provide an update on credit, and then I will return with some 2010 ou
componenttext:
Thank you, Jay. Welcome everyone. I will begin with review of our first quarter performance highlights, Don will follow with the detailed overview of our financial performance, Tim will provide an update on credit, and then I will return with some 2010 outlook comments what I hope you and other investors take away from todays presentation.
Let me begin the presentation turning to slide eight. We entered 2010 as a stronger company with underlying momentum and said we expected to return to profitability sometime in 2010. I am very pleased to report that sometime is now.
We reported net income of $39.7 million or $0.01 a share this morning. This is a very significant step forward and represents a reset of expectations for the year. But we now expect to report a profit for the full year 2010.
The results included a $38.2 million net tax benefit that Don will detail for you. As you think about the performance for the rest of the year, it's important to note that we continue to report very good improvement in pre-tax, pre-provision income. This was up 4% for the quarter and 16% annualized from the fourth quarter level and represented the fifth consecutive quarterly improvement. This is 12% higher than a year ago.
We believe this positive performance momentum will increasingly differentiate us from number of our peers over coming quarters. Primary driver was a 5% linked quarter increase in net interest income as our net interest margin expanded to 3.47% from 3.19% in the fourth quarter.
As we mentioned last quarter, the growth in investment securities in the fourth quarter was in short duration securities about 2.4-year duration. During the quarter, we modestly repositioned our interest rate risk position for more asset sensitivity for 2011. Don will provide details.
We now believe our net interest margin for the rest of the year will remain around a 3.5% level. Average loans declined slightly as decreases in total commercial loans were partially offset by growth in average total consumer loans.
Non-interest income was down due primarily to seasonal factors, though we saw good revenue growth in some key activities. The increases in expenses reflected a combination of seasonal factors, but also investments as well.
Credit quality trends continue to improve as expected across the board, NPAs declined 7%. Importantly, new NPAs for the quarter declined 52% and charge-offs declined for the quarter 46%, and we saw early stage delinquencies or commercial loans down 13% and consumer loans down 4%.
Turning to slide nine, while there are some signs of increasing economic stability in some of our markets, the economy remains challenging, and as such we thought it is important to maintain our reserve level essentially unchanged from where they were at the end of last year.
Our provision for credit loss is $235 million, essentially matching the $238 million in net charge-offs. Our allowance for credit losses as a percent of period loans and leases was 4.14%, this was down 2 bps from the prior quarter.
Relative to non-accrual loans, our reserve coverage ratio increased to 87% from 80%.
Our capital position is strong. Our tangible capital equity ratio improved 4 basis points to 5.96 during the last quarter. And in contrast our regulatory Tier 1 and Total risk-based capital ratios declined slightly due to an increase in the disallowed deferred tax assets. Nevertheless the ratios are still strong and are $2.5 billion and $1.8 billion respectively above well-capitalized regulatory thresholds.
Lastly, our liquidity position remained strong. We [fell] 5% annualized core deposit growth, and the period loan-to-deposit ratio was 92%. Period-end cash and investment securities were in excess of $10 billion.
As shown on slide 10, in addition to some well deserved recognition of the hard work and success of our colleagues in delivering high quality and value-added services in the area of automobile, finance and treasury management customers, we also continued to move forward with the implementation of strategic initiatives designed to grow revenue.
These included during the quarter, initiating 7-day banking in our Cleveland market, the first bank to do so; the addition of the team of seasoned commercial bankers in Michigan; the announcement of a 3-year $4 billion commitment to small business lending; the opening of two new Huntington Investment Company offices in central Ohio; and the hiring of nationally recognized mutual fund wholesaler to open up the distribution of our Huntington Funds through third-party channels.
Each of these initiatives is specifically targeted to grow revenues. We are very excited about the opportunities these represent. With that in mind, let me now turn the presentation over to Don for financial performance details. Don?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. As noted on slide 11, our net income for the first quarter was $39.7 million or $0.01 per share. One significant item impacted the quarter's results. We recognized the $38.2 million or $0.05 per share net benefit from an increase in the def
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. As noted on slide 11, our net income for the first quarter was $39.7 million or $0.01 per share. One significant item impacted the quarter's results. We recognized the $38.2 million or $0.05 per share net benefit from an increase in the deferred tax asset related to loans acquired from Franklin in 2009. This benefit was partially offset by the charge related to certain provisions of the Health Care and Education Reconciliation Act of 2010.
Slide 12 provides a summary of our quarterly earnings trend. The performance metrics will be discussed later in the presentation. So, lets move on.
On slide 13, we provide an overview of our pre-tax, pre-provision income performance. We believe this metric is useful in assessing underlying operating performance. We calculate this metric by starting out with pre-tax earnings and then excluding three items, provision for credit losses, security gains and losses and amortization of intangibles. We also adjusted certain significant items where applicable.
On this basis, our pre-tax, pre-provision income for the first quarter was $252 million, up $10 million or 4% from last quarter and 12% higher than a year ago. This improvement clearly reflected the management actions taken over the last year and we continue to look for additional opportunities to improve our operating results.
The most significant contributor to the improvement was our increased net interest income. This improvement will be detailed on the next slide.
Slide 14 depicts the trends of our net interest income and margin. During the first quarter, our fully taxable equivalent net interest income increased by $19.6 million reflecting a 28 basis point increase in our net interest margin of 3.47% and a $0.6 billion decrease to our average earning asset.
The margin change reflected several favorable impacts; first, with the favorable impact of our asset/liability management strategies. This impact primarily reflected two components.
First, in the third and fourth quarter of 2009, certain interest rate swaps were identified as ineffective. During the 2010 first quarter, we terminated most of these swaps and rebooked similar new swaps, resulting a positive impact on net interest income.
Second, we also entered into new swaps during the quarter to reduce our current asset sensitivity. The new swaps entered during the quarter were short in duration, an average of 1.7 years. While we are maintaining a very neutral interest rate position throughout all of 2010, we are positioned to become more asset-sensitive beginning in 2011. We have approximately $6 billion of interest rate swaps maturing in 2011.
Second, we also continue to see our margin benefit and a shift in our deposit mix as well as continued loan and deposit pricing efforts.
It is interesting to see that our margins have improved 50 basis points from a year ago. This improvement has occurred despite a shift in our overall asset mix, from loans to security, significantly improved liquidity position, maintaining a neutral interest rate risk position and a continued high level of non-performing assets.
Continuing on the slide 15, we show the linked-quarter loan and lease trends. Total commercial loans were down $1 billion or 5%. The decline reflected the anticipated decline in commercial real estate balances from pay-downs and charge-offs.
The $0.03 billion decline in C&I loans reflected the impact of a reclass of certain variable rate demand notes from commercial loans in prior periods to municipal securities. This reclass accounted for the entire decline in this linked-quarter balance.
Total consumer loans were up by $0.9 billion or 6% from the prior quarter. The $0.9 billion increase in average automobile loans and leases, primarily reflected the $0.8 billion impact of adopting new accounting standards to consolidate the previous off balance sheet automobile loan securitization transaction. These balances are recorded at fair value.
Also, during the quarter, our other loan originations remained strong.
Turning to slide 16, we continue to generate strong core deposit growth. Total core deposits grew at an annualized 5% rate despite a $0.9 billion decline in core time deposits.
We continue to be pleased with the shift in the mix of our deposit base to more transaction account. As noted earlier, this continued to drive the improvement in our net interest margin.
Slide 17 shows the trends in our non-interest income category. Our non-interest income declined $3.7 million from the prior quarter. Deposit service charges were down reflecting both normal seasonal trends and the continued change in consumer behavior to reduce the underlying NSF/OD activity.
Other income declined by $5.4 million as much as the prior quarter's benefit from derivatives ineffectiveness was recorded in other non-interest income. Our brokerage and insurance revenues were up $3.6 million, reflecting the impact of seasonally higher contingent insurance income and a stronger sales volume.
The next slide is a summary of our expense trends. Total expenses were up $75.5 million from the prior quarter. This was primarily due to the fourth quarter $73.6 million gain on the debt redemption.
Personnel costs were up $3 million reflecting the seasonal impact of higher employment taxes and high debt increases related to our strategic initiatives. We are encouraged to see the $7 million decline in the OREO foreclosure expense.
Slide 19 is a summary of our capital trend. The current quarter's profit resulted in a slight increase to our TCE ratio from 5.92% to 5.96%. In contrast, regulatory capital ratio has declined slightly, reflecting a disallowance of a greater portion of our deferred tax assets.
