componenttext: And our next question comes from the line of Scott Siefers with Sandler O'Neill.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, I guess, the first question is probably for you, just on the level of the reserve. And you said last quarter that despite maybe drawing down the allowance being part of the outlook, it wouldn't be necessarily a big earnings driver. I guess, just gi
componenttext: Steve, I guess, the first question is probably for you, just on the level of the reserve. And you said last quarter that despite maybe drawing down the allowance being part of the outlook, it wouldn't be necessarily a big earnings driver. I guess, just given another 90 days, what's the data in your kind of more upbeat commentary on credit? Did that still hold true or might there be a bit more material reserve release throughout the year?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, the reserve release will be timed to material improvement change in credit quality, and we do expect credit quality to get better. But in terms of the commentary about profitability for the year, it's not contingent on a reserve release. We're expec
componenttext: Well, the reserve release will be timed to material improvement change in credit quality, and we do expect credit quality to get better. But in terms of the commentary about profitability for the year, it's not contingent on a reserve release. We're expecting it to be able to drive it from the quarter. And if this reserve release based on improved asset quality, that would be incremental.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then Don, I have this separate question for you. I was just hoping you could just try a little more color on the margin. I guess, it's sort of two separate questions within there. I guess, if I have thought about it a year ago and I guess today, someb
componenttext: And then Don, I have this separate question for you. I was just hoping you could just try a little more color on the margin. I guess, it's sort of two separate questions within there. I guess, if I have thought about it a year ago and I guess today, somebody's going to stay neutral from a rate perspective, will increase their liquidity and will be increasing the percentage of securities relative to loan. That wouldn't necessarily -- except the margin was going to improve anywhere near what your guidance did. I certainly understand everything that's going on the deposit side, but maybe if you can just give a little more color on the improvement. And then conversely, just given the opportunity, it looks like it's still there on the CD side. Why wouldn't there be some more expansion beyond what we've seen already?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the margin expansion, you're right. There were a couple of factors that helped drive it for us this year. If you look at the deposit mix change, about half of that 50 basis points is really coming from that mix change that we saw throughout the
componenttext: As far as the margin expansion, you're right. There were a couple of factors that helped drive it for us this year. If you look at the deposit mix change, about half of that 50 basis points is really coming from that mix change that we saw throughout the year. I attribute most of the rest of that margin improvement coming from both deposit and loan pricing, that we're seeing much wider spreads on loan originations than we were, say, 18 months ago, and our deposit rates for new time deposits and other products have come down as well. So that's helping us to drive the margins. So I'd say, those are both contributing factors.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe just add, presumably there's a little more mix opportunity on the deposit side, particularly with CDs. When will that maybe help the margin expand a bit more than the current outlook would suggest?
componenttext: And then maybe just add, presumably there's a little more mix opportunity on the deposit side, particularly with CDs. When will that maybe help the margin expand a bit more than the current outlook would suggest?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A couple of things. One is that the first quarter does benefit from the day count. So there's about a four basis point lift from the margin from that, compared to future quarters. I'd say that the other constrained factor is that this quarter, our average
componenttext: A couple of things. One is that the first quarter does benefit from the day count. So there's about a four basis point lift from the margin from that, compared to future quarters. I'd say that the other constrained factor is that this quarter, our average earning assets were down slightly. We expect our deposit growth to continue to outpace our loan growth throughout this year. And as that adds to earning assets, we don't get the same incremental 3.5% spread on investment securities, compared to the deposit accounts. And so we think, that can be a deterrent to the overall margin, even though will be added to net interest income.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Tony Davis with Stifel, Nicolaus.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Tony Davis with Stifel, Nicolaus.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Slide 25 shows this gradual decline in loan sales, and I'm just wondering what happened to the pace of raw land and lot dispositions here recently. And what we probably should expect from the SAD folks' efforts here, going forward, in terms of a quarterly
componenttext: Slide 25 shows this gradual decline in loan sales, and I'm just wondering what happened to the pace of raw land and lot dispositions here recently. And what we probably should expect from the SAD folks' efforts here, going forward, in terms of a quarterly disposition rate?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're in a seasonal slow in the first quarter, Tony. And you'll see it pick up in Q3 and maybe four [Q4], but certainly, two [Q2] or three [Q3], at this point. And these are OREO sales. So we would expect activity to be consistent with prior periods. Any
componenttext: You're in a seasonal slow in the first quarter, Tony. And you'll see it pick up in Q3 and maybe four [Q4], but certainly, two [Q2] or three [Q3], at this point. And these are OREO sales. So we would expect activity to be consistent with prior periods. Anything you want to add, Tim?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think, that's exactly right, that the seasonality is perhaps, the biggest factor. We're moving into a time frame where the markets have opened up a little bit, and there are going to be interested parties in the properties.
componenttext: No. I think, that's exactly right, that the seasonality is perhaps, the biggest factor. We're moving into a time frame where the markets have opened up a little bit, and there are going to be interested parties in the properties.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Steve, do you have any thoughts in mind about how long it might take to unwind the non-core CRE component?
componenttext: Steve, do you have any thoughts in mind about how long it might take to unwind the non-core CRE component?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said last time, we think, it's at least a couple of years. It could be longer. There's some encouraging signs about CMBS markets starting to open up. I think, there was as a multi-issuer. But I don't see it coming back quickly. And conversely,
componenttext: Well, as we said last time, we think, it's at least a couple of years. It could be longer. There's some encouraging signs about CMBS markets starting to open up. I think, there was as a multi-issuer. But I don't see it coming back quickly. And conversely, I don't see any -- we are not feeling pressure to dump it or to get to a disposition. We're going to do this with a lot of focus around capital impacts and make the best decisions. Running with this level of NPAs and a 3.5 NIM, I wouldn't have thought possible last year. So we'll keep working it, reducing it. Remember that in the event, as you get roughly $350 million of Franklin, that's already marked. So we're chided just because of the rats were reporting something that distorts us a bit, penalizes us, if you will, with a higher level of NPL.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're already gearing up in asset-based lending, I know. And I guess, the question is, as the runoffs continue in the riskier segments, what we should expect a reasonable time period, in terms of when do we see a re-emergence of aggregate loan growth, as
componenttext: You're already gearing up in asset-based lending, I know. And I guess, the question is, as the runoffs continue in the riskier segments, what we should expect a reasonable time period, in terms of when do we see a re-emergence of aggregate loan growth, as the years play out?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's a part of a function of the economy. There's an increasingly competitive market. All the banks are facing runoff. And so that's changing the competitive dynamics fairly quickly. There is not an enormous amount of net new investment or demand. I think
componenttext: It's a part of a function of the economy. There's an increasingly competitive market. All the banks are facing runoff. And so that's changing the competitive dynamics fairly quickly. There is not an enormous amount of net new investment or demand. I think, we started to see some stability in outlook that could change in the second half. But for us, I think, we're going to be replacing non-core real estate amortization with C&I and maybe some consumer growth for a while. So I think, our capital efficiency is going to get better over time, but not necessarily a lot of growth in the balance sheet.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Patten with Morgan Keegan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Bob Patten with Morgan Keegan.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just have two parts to the same question, and it's really about thinking forward, the big picture. It really revolves on how does Huntington build capital, if you look at Q1 comment, it's about 6.5%.  A lot of the raises we have seen to date have raised
componenttext: I just have two parts to the same question, and it's really about thinking forward, the big picture. It really revolves on how does Huntington build capital, if you look at Q1 comment, it's about 6.5%.  A lot of the raises we have seen to date have raised it above that quite a bit. We look at the balance sheet  now, the shrinkage is mostly behind you. And then if you look at sort of the issues around what you need to do to pay off of TARP, and I'm respectful of how you described it, for us Steve. I'm not looking to pin you down, but just the thought process. You have to be profitable, you guys are there. The view is you had to show access to the capital market, so maybe some debt raising at some point. What is your thought process on how Huntington begins to build capital?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: First, I think, it comes from the core. As you know, we're intending to increase pre-tax, pre-provision. And at the same time, with credit metrics improving, should get the [ph] roughly the rate that we saw in the first and fourth quarters, we're going to
componenttext: First, I think, it comes from the core. As you know, we're intending to increase pre-tax, pre-provision. And at the same time, with credit metrics improving, should get the [ph] roughly the rate that we saw in the first and fourth quarters, we're going to be in a position where we're going to have to look at reducing the overall level of reserves. So a combination of those factors, there is potential, I think, as markets stabilize, perhaps in some other respects for now, the deferred tax asset over time. And we may even see some OTTI or OCI, as markets again stabilize. But principally, at this point, from earnings.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Steve, within the process, who is your key regulator in this decision process, when you finally did get to the point you want to address the issue of paying off TARP?
componenttext: And Steve, within the process, who is your key regulator in this decision process, when you finally did get to the point you want to address the issue of paying off TARP?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: TARP for the bank holding company, would be the key decision maker is Fed. You start with your primary bank regulators support. But the Fed has, in effect, final say.
componenttext: TARP for the bank holding company, would be the key decision maker is Fed. You start with your primary bank regulators support. But the Fed has, in effect, final say.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Bob, I think, to add a few comments that Steve made there, as far as our capital ratio, keep in mind, as Steve said, the DTA negatively impacts us. That's about a four-basis-point impact to our Tier 1 common ratio as that will come back organically throug
componenttext: Bob, I think, to add a few comments that Steve made there, as far as our capital ratio, keep in mind, as Steve said, the DTA negatively impacts us. That's about a four-basis-point impact to our Tier 1 common ratio as that will come back organically through the earnings generation over the next couple of years. The other thing that Huntington is a little bit different than some of our peers as well, is that we have a convertible preferred. That's not TARP, our normal convertible preferred. If you would add that to our Tier 1 common equivalent, it's another 70 basis points. So those two combined, would put us over 8% on a core basis, adjusting to those two items. And we think, that puts us in very good standing, as far as our capital position.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Terry McEvoy with Oppenheimer.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Terry McEvoy with Oppenheimer.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question, with credit becoming less of a concern, more of a focus now on revenue growth. It seems to be there's maybe a consensus too that the Midwest is just not a growth market, and the only wait for a bank like Huntington to show organic growt
componenttext: Just one question, with credit becoming less of a concern, more of a focus now on revenue growth. It seems to be there's maybe a consensus too that the Midwest is just not a growth market, and the only wait for a bank like Huntington to show organic growth would be through market share gains. Would you agree with that statement? Do you think it's maybe a little too aggressive? And then, as you look at your market share on both sides of the balance sheet, do you think, with maybe the new energy that Huntington has, there's the ability to grow market share in your core markets?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We believe so, Terry, on both sides of the sheet.
componenttext: We believe so, Terry, on both sides of the sheet.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And in terms of just your overall comments on the Midwest, as you talk to your customers, do you get a sense that there is organic growth, in terms of loan demand business activity, to surprise the markets on the upside over the next few years?
componenttext: And in terms of just your overall comments on the Midwest, as you talk to your customers, do you get a sense that there is organic growth, in terms of loan demand business activity, to surprise the markets on the upside over the next few years?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, auto, clearly, would be up year-over-year. We just had a series of small business roundtables in six markets, such maybe 100 small business. I would say, the vast majority of those business owners were bullish about this year, in terms of revenue up
componenttext: Well, auto, clearly, would be up year-over-year. We just had a series of small business roundtables in six markets, such maybe 100 small business. I would say, the vast majority of those business owners were bullish about this year, in terms of revenue up, and the majority expected a higher. And I think, the majority also expected to make some capital investment. Now that proves to be reflective of the market, overall. That could be a little more positive than expectation. Having said that, it's still -- Midwest gets painted in one brush. It's more diverse than that. But there still is a very tough area in the Midwest than in our primary market. So there's some reasons for optimism, but I would view it cautiously.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Bank of America.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ken Usdin with Bank of America.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one question on Commercial Real Estate, I was just wondering if you could just give us a little color on migration trends within that book. Obviously, the early stage doing with you look good.  But can you just kind of walk us through single family h
componenttext: Just one question on Commercial Real Estate, I was just wondering if you could just give us a little color on migration trends within that book. Obviously, the early stage doing with you look good.  But can you just kind of walk us through single family homebuilder? That seems to be pretty much stressed. Can you just take us through kind of the sub-buckets and give us a sense of confidence you have that you've met it down on that book?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Why don't I start with the comment, and then I'll work off Page 92 in the deck, for those of you who have the deck. And you saw a little bit of reduction in the core $68 million, and the combination of charge-offs and other changes drive the non-core down
componenttext: Why don't I start with the comment, and then I'll work off Page 92 in the deck, for those of you who have the deck. And you saw a little bit of reduction in the core $68 million, and the combination of charge-offs and other changes drive the non-core down. Importantly, for us, the core was very stable in the first quarter. We had only one relationship out of all the relationships in the core, become a set back, and that happened at the end of the quarter, because of some unexpected lease issues in a property that we don't finance, but has impacted for our -- in a significant way. So we're feeling, if we could buy that performance for the course of this year, we'll do it today. We're feeling very good about the quarter. Then I'll take you to the buckets. I'll turn it over to Tim and you, what page are you going to work up there?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, I'm not sure, their page. I only discussed through a couple of them. A, single family, as we talked about last quarter, we really feel that that's not a major driver of performance, going forward...
componenttext: I guess, I'm not sure, their page. I only discussed through a couple of them. A, single family, as we talked about last quarter, we really feel that that's not a major driver of performance, going forward...

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Slide 88.
componenttext: Slide 88.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then that bucket is, in fact, retail. Retail continues to be an issue across our markets. We've been very active in the ongoing portfolio management of those properties or that product type, and you can see on 87, what our current performance is. We a
componenttext: And then that bucket is, in fact, retail. Retail continues to be an issue across our markets. We've been very active in the ongoing portfolio management of those properties or that product type, and you can see on 87, what our current performance is. We are happy with some of it. Delinquencies are flat. The classified number is, in fact, up. But non-accruals are down a little bit. Reserves are down a little bit. So we really feel like that's flattening out, as the overall portfolio metrics would indicate. The rest of the portfolio is comprised of office, warehouse, would be a couple of the other drivers. We've never had a material issue with the office space. It's primarily suburban, so there is no downtown business district powers that we have to worry about. And the rest of the portfolio, we continue to work aggressively on. I really think, that commercial real estate, Steve's comments around the core versus non-core are where we're focused, going forward.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I guess, one quick follow-up just on franchise geography. Can you just give us a little color on how the different areas of the franchise you expected to rebound and kind of where they are in their economic recovery? A couple of banks have even mentio
componenttext: And I guess, one quick follow-up just on franchise geography. Can you just give us a little color on how the different areas of the franchise you expected to rebound and kind of where they are in their economic recovery? A couple of banks have even mentioned that Michigan may be starting to bottom a little bit. I'd love to get your thoughts on that as well.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The auto zone, which would be East Michigan, Toledo through Cleveland, very, very challenged, may be flattening out right now. But it's flattening out at a dip. Western Michigan is slightly different than East. Indi [Indianapolis], Cincinnati, Columbus, P
componenttext: The auto zone, which would be East Michigan, Toledo through Cleveland, very, very challenged, may be flattening out right now. But it's flattening out at a dip. Western Michigan is slightly different than East. Indi [Indianapolis], Cincinnati, Columbus, Pittsburgh and West Virginia are actually getting through the cycle in pretty good shape. So we almost have a [indiscernible] in our footprint. Is that what you were looking for or you want more?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was just wondering, would you expect to see resumption of growth coming out of the Michigan footprint on the loan side? Or is it kind of give you more from the other parts of the footprint as we come out of the cycle?
componenttext: I was just wondering, would you expect to see resumption of growth coming out of the Michigan footprint on the loan side? Or is it kind of give you more from the other parts of the footprint as we come out of the cycle?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We'll see it in Western Michigan. And I think, perhaps later this year, but not near term and maybe East if it just keeps going. But our demand will primarily come out of the Indianapolis Cincinnati, Columbus, Pittsburgh markets.
componenttext: We'll see it in Western Michigan. And I think, perhaps later this year, but not near term and maybe East if it just keeps going. But our demand will primarily come out of the Indianapolis Cincinnati, Columbus, Pittsburgh markets.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Erika Penala with UBS.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Erika Penala with UBS.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is on the fee income guidance for the year. Could you remind us how much NSF/overdraft is over your deposit service charges? And what you estimated to be the impact of Reg E?
componenttext: My first question is on the fee income guidance for the year. Could you remind us how much NSF/overdraft is over your deposit service charges? And what you estimated to be the impact of Reg E?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I can do is provide all the color as far as the NSF/OD that's just, going to be approximately base line of about $300 million of deposit service charges a year. About $180 million of that come from NSF/OD overall.  Roughly about $100 million come fro
componenttext: What I can do is provide all the color as far as the NSF/OD that's just, going to be approximately base line of about $300 million of deposit service charges a year. About $180 million of that come from NSF/OD overall.  Roughly about $100 million come from the NSF/OD, associated with either ATM, debit card transaction. So that's the potential universe, I guess, as far as the impact. We haven't officially disclosed what our plan is, as far as addressing that. But we are working through that and do believe that we'll be able to mitigate losses associated with some of the Reg E impact that we'll try to provide more color at end of the second quarter, as the actual plans and the limitation plan associated with that.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my second question is on the restructured resi [residential] mortgage. I assume those are mostly are all loan mods [loan modification], the $243 million.
componenttext: And my second question is on the restructured resi [residential] mortgage. I assume those are mostly are all loan mods [loan modification], the $243 million.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: That's correct.
componenttext: That's correct.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you share with us the reserve that you've taken for that $243 million and what the underlying re-default rate you've assumed, when determining that reserve?
componenttext: And could you share with us the reserve that you've taken for that $243 million and what the underlying re-default rate you've assumed, when determining that reserve?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know the reserves specifically associated with those loans. We can get that for you, if you'd like. I can tell you that only 27% is -- about the number, have gone delinquent subsequent to the loan modification/restructure. So we're reasonably plea
componenttext: I don't know the reserves specifically associated with those loans. We can get that for you, if you'd like. I can tell you that only 27% is -- about the number, have gone delinquent subsequent to the loan modification/restructure. So we're reasonably pleased with that recidivism rate, compared to some of the industry numbers we've seen.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how long is the forbearance period typically?
componenttext: And how long is the forbearance period typically?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that there is a typical number on that. We would generally be solving issues. We could have a one-year look or a two-year look. We're not creating 30-year fixed adjustments.
componenttext: I don't know that there is a typical number on that. We would generally be solving issues. We could have a one-year look or a two-year look. We're not creating 30-year fixed adjustments.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And our final question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: And our final question comes from the line of Brian Foran with Goldman Sachs.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As we think past the third quarter and the $275 million of pre-provision target you would be at then, what are kind of the key positive and negatives that would make you go higher or flat line from there? And I guess, is it more about the environment and
componenttext: As we think past the third quarter and the $275 million of pre-provision target you would be at then, what are kind of the key positive and negatives that would make you go higher or flat line from there? And I guess, is it more about the environment and resumption of C&I loan growth and things like that? Or are there further internal opportunities that could drive pre-provision higher than $275 million, even if the environment remains sluggish?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are going to take the rest of the year off after hitting $275 million in the third quarter, you can be assured of that. But we think there are a number of initiatives. The growth of the $275 million is coming in a economic environment that's very chall
componenttext: We are going to take the rest of the year off after hitting $275 million in the third quarter, you can be assured of that. But we think there are a number of initiatives. The growth of the $275 million is coming in a economic environment that's very challenged. We think, that once the economy does start to recover, we will see a rebound in our commercial lending balances and other activity, as you suggested. But more importantly, as part of our strategic planning process, we're identifying other factors that can help move the dial even further. And one of the key components of that is to continue to deepen our share of wallet with our existing customers. And so focusing on that will continue to be a driver for it, as far as continued improvement in that pre-tax, pre-provision operating earnings.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And we have no further question at this time. Sir, do you have any closing remarks?
componenttext: And we have no further question at this time. Sir, do you have any closing remarks?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Christopher, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the Huntington Bancshares second quarter earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any bac
componenttext:
Good afternoon. My name is Christopher, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time I would like to welcome everyone to the Huntington Bancshares second quarter earnings conference call. All lines have been placed on mute to prevent any background noise. After the speakers remarks there will be a question-and-answer session. (Operator instructions) Thank you.
Mr. Gould, you may begin your conference.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christopher, and welcome everybody. I am Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides, we will be reviewing, can be found on our Web site, huntington.com.This call is being recorded and will be available as a
componenttext:
Thank you, Christopher, and welcome everybody. I am Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides, we will be reviewing, can be found on our Web site, huntington.com.
This call is being recorded and will be available as a rebroadcast starting about one hour from the close of the call. Please call the Investor Relations department at 614-480-5676 for more information on how to access these recordings or playback or should you have difficulty getting a copy of the slides.
Slides two, three and four on your deck note several aspects of the basis of todays presentation. I encourage you to read these, but let me point out one key disclosure. This presentation contains both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures, and where we believe its helpful to understanding Huntingtons results of operations or financial position.
Where non-GAAP financial measures are used, the comparable GAAP financial measure, as well as the reconciliation to the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found in the slide presentation, in its appendix, in the press release, in the quarterly financial review supplement to todays earnings press release, or in the related Form 8-K filed later today, all of these can be found on our Web site.
Turning to slide five, todays discussion including the Q&A period may contain forward-looking statements. Such statements are based on information and assumptions available at this time, and are subject to changes, risks and uncertainties, which may cause actual results to differ materially. We assume no obligation to update such statements. For a complete discussion of risks and uncertainties, please refer to this slide, and material filed with the SEC, including our most recent forms 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K.
Now, turning to todays presentation. As noted on slide six, participating today are Steve Steinour, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Don Kimble, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer, and Tim Barber, Senior Vice President of Credit Risk Management.
Also present, and by way of introduction is, Todd Beekman. He recently joined us as Assistant Director of Investor Relations. He was formerly with Fidelity Management and Research in Boston, where he was an Analyst, including several years as a Regional Bank Analyst. Many of you, I know, know Todd. We look forward to his contribution to our IR effort.
Lets get started now by turning to slide seven, Steve?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome, everyone. Ill begin with the review of the second quarter performance highlights. After my overview, Don will detail how Franklin impacted our numbers and then follow with his usual overview of our financial performance. Tim will provide an up
componenttext:
Welcome, everyone. Ill begin with the review of the second quarter performance highlights. After my overview, Don will detail how Franklin impacted our numbers and then follow with his usual overview of our financial performance. Tim will provide an update on credit. I will then return with the discussion of the impact of recent regulatory changes and 2010 outlook comments.
While we will provide the detail in a moment, I want to point out a couple of key achievements. Overall, we are very pleased with the second quarter performance. We reported higher profits than last quarter. We saw a 3% linked-quarter growth in revenue, even after excluding a $14.2 million increase in MSR valuations. Our capital ratios meaningfully improved during the quarter.
As expected we saw significant declines in nonperforming assets inflows, as inflows of new NPAs and criticized assets continued to fall. Our period-end nonaccruing loan reserve coverage ratio jumped to 120% from 87%. So in sum, another meaningful step forward, moving Huntington to stronger financial performance.
At the end of the quarter we transferred all of our Franklin loans to -for-sale, and subsequent to quarter-end, we sold $274 million of this exposure, which had a significant impact on second quarter performance as it resulted in a $75.5 million charge-off and also $75.5 million of provision expense, a negative $0.07 per share.
There was another $4.5 million in net charge-offs in provision expenses associated with Franklin in the second quarter prior to the transfer into held-for-sale. Don will detail all of this for you later in his presentation. It is important to understand that this transfer into held-for-sale and subsequent sale was a very positive development.
Lets begin a more detailed presentation. Turning to slide eight, we reported net income of $48.8 million or $0.03 per share. This was a significant achievement. The drivers were substantially improved credit quality and higher pre-tax pre-provision income. We believe these trends will continue.
Our pre-tax pre-provision income was $270.5 million, a 7% improvement from the first quarter and an 18% improvement from a year earlier. This represented our sixth consecutive quarter improvement. The primary driver was a 5% linked-quarter increase in revenue, reflecting 2% growth in fully taxable equivalent net interest income and a 12% increase in non-interest income. This was partially offset by a 4% linked-quarter increase in non-interest expense.
The growth in fully taxable equivalent net interest income reflected modest growth in average total loans. We saw very strong growth in average automobile loans, and leases up 9% as we continue to take advantage of competitive dislocations and benefited from strategic initiatives to expand our in franchise footprint.
Average residential mortgages grew 3%. Partially offsetting these increases were a 4% decline in average commercial real estate loans as we continued to reduce net exposure.
Our average commercial and industrial loans declined slightly. Period end C&I loans were up 1% from the end of March or 3% on the accruing portfolio. Utilization rates remained historically low and relatively unchanged.
So this reflects a combination of several factors, including few opportunities for companies to expand given the weak economy, companies continuing to build strong cash positions, and a general lack of confidence that is postponing investment decisions.
Average total investment securities increased 3% as we continued to deploy funds from a strong growth in core deposits. Our net interest margin was 3.46%, down a basis point of which 6 basis points related to Franklin loans.
Non-interest income increased 12% driven mostly by a $14.2 million increase in MSR valuations, primarily reflecting lower prepayment assumptions, though we also benefited from a 34% increase in mortgage originations, which contributed a $6.2 million increase in origination and secondary market income. Non-interest income also benefited from an increase in seasonal service charges on deposit accounts.
The increase in expenses reflected our continued investment in growth. The real highlight for the quarter was continued significant improvement in credit quality. This improvement reflects clearly the benefit of last years focused actions to address credit related problems.
We anticipate continued improvement over the second half of this year. On a linked-quarter basis, nonperforming assets declined 17% and we saw a 28% decrease in new non-performing assets.
We also saw an 8% decline in newly identified criticized commercial loans. While reported net charge-offs increased from the prior quarter, excluding Franklin-related charge-offs, they were down 12%, after also adjusting the prior period Franklin-related net charge-offs.
Our provision for credit losses was $193.4 million or $117.9 million excluding the $75.5 million related to Franklin. Both 30 and 90-day delinquencies continued to decline.
Turning to slide nine, our period-end allowance for credit losses as a percentage of total loan and leases declined to 3.9%. Importantly and reflecting substantial improvement in credit quality trends, our nonaccrual loan coverage ratio jumped to 120% from 87%. Our capital position is solid with increases in all of our capital ratios.
Our regulatory Tier 1 and total risk-based capital ratios are $2.8 billion and $2 billion above well capitalized regulatory thresholds. Tangible common equity ratio improved 16 bps to 6.12% and our Tier 1 common risk-based capital ratio improved 51 bps to 7.04%.
Lastly, our liquidity position remained strong. We saw 6% annualized core deposit growth, with a period-end loan-to-deposit ratio of 93%.
As shown on slide #10, we continue move forward with the implementation of strategic initiatives designed to grow future revenue. These included the hiring and appointment of new key executives in revenue generating businesses. In our commercial banking segment this included a new Director of Commercial Banking, in Central Ohio, and new Regional President in the Greater Cleveland area, and a new President of our Equipment Finance Group. In our Private Financial Group this included a new President of Unified Fund Services, a new Chief Operating Officer for Huntington Insurance, and hiring a new team of trust and private bankers in Dayton, Ohio.
We also made progress in expanding and upgrading our distribution capabilities. In our retail and business banking segment, we have begun the rebranding and refurbishing of banking offices, and initiated in-store and retirement centre expansion. Within PFG we opened a new office in Wheeling, West Virginia and a family office in Columbus devoted to assisting high net worth families with managing and preserving generational wealth.
In support of our initiative to improve cross-sell performance we launched the first phase of our sales force referral automation system called MAX. We have kicked off a strategic plan refresh looking out over the next three years.
Each of these initiatives is specifically targeted to grow revenues. The appendix on slide is showing all the other initiatives since the first quarter of 2009. We are very excited about the cumulative impact and the opportunities these initiatives represent.
Turning to slide #11, its important to understand Franklins impact on the quarter as well as our rationale for this action. Earlier at the end of the quarter we transferred all our Franklin-related loans to held-for-sale resulting in $75.5 million net charge-off.
One contributing factor to higher bank stock valuation is the demonstrated ability to consistently deliver credit quality performance that is better than peers. Thats our objective and what we want to be known for.
As related to Franklin, since our restructuring in early 2009, this portfolio has performed as expected and we were prepared to hold these loans through maturity. However, a negative side effect to retain these loans has been poorer relative credit quality performance metrics. The confluence of second quarter events gave us the opportunity to essentially bring this relationship to a close by moving these loans in the held-for-sale.
As the quarter progressed, we saw renewed buyer interest in distressed debt. That was also positive.
In contrast, we saw an economic outlook turn more uncertain. Further, the expiration of the tax credits for home purchases and indications that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac might accelerate home foreclosures and sales of OREOs raised concern that residential real estate prices could be under pressure over time, which would lower the value of the collateral supporting these loans.
So late in the quarter, we made a decision to move these loans to held-for-sale, which resulted in the $75.5 million of charge-offs, which was disappointing on one hand. However, I am pleased to report that on July 20, we sold $274 million of the Franklin-related residential mortgages.
Importantly, given todays much stronger balance sheet and earnings performance, we were able to absorb the related charge-offs and still report growth in earnings and higher capital ratios.
This sale adds to overall future financial performance as we reinvest the proceeds and no longer have to absorb related portfolio servicing and other support costs. It more quickly moves us toward obtaining our objective of better than peer credit quality performance metrics.
Let me turn the presentation over to Don to review the details.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. The second column on slide #12 details the impact of the transfer of the Franklin-related loans to held-for-sale. Third column shows other Franklin-related net charge-offs, that is those that occurred during the quarter prior to the transfe
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. The second column on slide #12 details the impact of the transfer of the Franklin-related loans to held-for-sale. Third column shows other Franklin-related net charge-offs, that is those that occurred during the quarter prior to the transfer to held-for-sale. The last column shows the impact from excluding these Franklin-related items.
Focusing on the second column, as of June 30, $398 million of Franklin-related loans were charged down to $323 million and transferred to held-for-sale. This resulted in $75.5 million of charge-offs and related provision expense.
$14.7 million of the charge-offs were related to Franklin-related home equity loans and $60.8 million of Franklin-related residential mortgages, and adding in the other $4.5 million of Franklin-related net charge-offs, total Franklin net charge-offs in the quarter were $80 million. Net charge-offs as reported and as adjusted to exclude Franklin-related net charge-offs are shown on this slide.
For additional detail and a reconciliation of the impact that Franklin issues on the current as well as prior quarters for all credit-related metrics, please refer to the Franklin reconciliation slides in the appendix.
As Steve noted earlier, the sale of the residential real estate loans was closed on Tuesday, which reduced our NPAs by $225 million. This will reduce our NPA ratio from 4.24% to 3.65%.
Turning to slide #13, our net income for the second quarter was $48.8 million or $0.03 per share. The impact of our transfer of the Franklin loans to held-for-sale is a one significant item impacting the quarters results. As discussed earlier, we recognized a $75.5 million or $0.07 per share provision expense related to the transfer. This impact is net of estimated selling cost.
Slide #14 provides a summary of our quarterly earnings trends. Many of the performance metrics will be discussed later in the presentation, so lets move on.
On Slide #15, we provide an overview of our pre-tax pre-provision income performance. We continue to believe this metric is useful in assessing the underlying operating performance.
We calculate this metric by starting with pre-tax earnings, and then excluding three items; provision for credit losses, security gains and losses, and amortization of intangibles. We also adjust for certain significant items where applicable.
On this basis, our pre-tax pre-provision income for the second quarter was $270 million, up $18 million or 7% from last quarter and 18% higher than a year ago.
Slide #16 depicts the trends of our net interest income and margins. During the second quarter, our fully tax equivalent net interest income increased by $6 million, reflecting a 1 basis point decline in our net interest margin of 3.46% and a $0.3 billion increased to our average earning asset base.
The margin change reflected several items. First was the impact of the deposit mix and pricing changes. The mix shift from time deposits to more transaction based core deposits not only reduces our cost, but also produces a more stable deposit base for us as well.
Offsetting this positive impact was a $6.8 million of 6 basis points reduction in the margin coming from the Franklin-related loans. During the first quarter we received more payments on loans that had been already reduced to a zero balance resulting in additional interest income. These payments slowed significantly in the second quarter.
Other items impacting the quarter included lower interest income on our interest derivatives and in part due to changes in the interest rate environment. Also the day count negatively impacted the second quarter margin.
Going forward we expect some of the same trends, with the Franklin-related sale having a slight reduction to the margin, but a positive impact to the bottom line after considering the servicing cost previously incurred.
Continuing on to slide #17, it shows the changed in our deposits mix over the last five quarters. This shift from 45% of the deposits in time and noncore funds of 29% has improved the margin by 22 basis points.
This mix will also have some impact on the third quarter from the expiration of the TAGP program. We saw $100 million move from transaction accounts to other products including sweep accounts and short-term liabilities.
We also saw approximately $600 million reduction to our deposits as a result of requirements for FDIC coverage. Overall, this performance was in line to better than our expectations. We also have one quarter left with higher price to time deposits running off.
Turning to Slide #18, we continue to generate strong core deposit growth. Total core deposits grew at an annualized 6% rate despite a $0.8 billion decline in average noncore deposits.
Slide #19 shows the trends on loan and lease portfolio. This was the first quarter in the last six that we have actually shown loan growth. Total commercial loans were down $0.4 billion or 2%.
The decline reflected the anticipated decline in commercial real estate balances. The $0.1 billion decline in C&I loans reflected the continued de-leveraging from our commercial customers. However, we did experience a $147 million increase period-end balance from March 31 to June 30.
Total consumer loans were up $0.5 billion or 3% from the prior quarter. The $0.4 billion increase in average automobile loans and leases reflected record originations of over $900 million this past quarter. These originations continue to reflect very high credit quality and reasonable returns.
Slide #20 shows the trends in our non-interest income categories. Our non-interest income increased by $28.8 million from the prior quarter. Our mortgage banking revenues increased by $20.5 million, reflecting a $14 million increase to the net MSR hedging income. This increase reflected a reduction to the underlying prepayment assumption for FCMC MSR asset. These prepayment assumptions were accelerated throughout 2009 with the expectations that the government programs would increase the refinance activity.
We continued to use a third party to assist in valuing the MSR asset and in other to help validate the value assigned. Deposits service charges were up $6.6 million and electronic banking revenues were up $3 million, both reflecting normal seasonal trend.
The next slide is a summary of our expense trends. Total expenses were up $15.7 million from the prior quarter. This reflected an $11.2 million or 6% increases in personnel cost. This increase was due to a 4% increase in staffing levels attributed to strategic initiatives implemented over the last two quarters, the full quarter impact of merit increases awarded late in the first quarter and the reinstatement of the companys 401(k) plan matching contribution.
Marketing costs were up $6.5 million attributed to brand advertising campaign launched in the second quarter. Other expenses were up $2.8 million, including a $5.4 million increase in cost related to reps and warranties on mortgage loan sales. $4 million of this increase was attributed to an increase to the reserve for this liability as we are using a more forward-looking estimate reflecting the increased cost of the current quarter. Offsetting these increases were declines in OREO with foreclosure expenses as well as seasonal claims and occupancy costs.
Slide #22, is a summary of our capital trends. The current quarters profit resulted in an increase to our tangible common equity ratio from 5.96% to 6.12%, but reflecting even stronger improvement were the regulatory capital ratios.
Our Tier 1 common ratio increased to 7.04% from 6.53% and our Tier 1 ratio increased to 12.47% from 11.97%. These increases not only benefited from the capital accretive earnings, but also from a decrease in the total disallowed deferred tax asset for regulatory capital purposes from $390 million at March 31 to $191 million at June 30, as a result of recognition of the tax impact of the Franklin-related charge-offs. The deferred tax asset realization for regulatory capital purposes improved the ratios by approximately 47 basis points.
Turning to Slide #23, one cannot talk about capital without some mention of our plans to repay our $1.4 billion in TARP capital. We believe that were better positioned for repayment today. We have strong balance sheet liquidity and our current regulatory capital is over $2 billion in excess of the existing well-capitalized thresholds.
With another quarter of profitable performance and expectations of continued profitability, were back to generating capital internally. However, and as noted last quarter, we believe there are three factors for consideration before repayment.
The first is consistent demonstrated profitable performance with growth in earnings. We believe were on our way to get (inaudible) quarters in a row. The second is evidence of a sustained economic recovery. This outlook turned a little more negative this past quarter and while we think the economy is stabilizing, it remains fragile.
Third, having better clarity on any new regulatory capital thresholds would be helpful. While the recently passed Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act gave the authority to set these standards, it will be some time before the specific regulations are written. We think our current ratios are above where these new thresholds may eventually be set, but thats not a certainty.
Based on other banks that have had to raise capital at the time they repaid their TARP, it is likely that we will have to raise capital as well. While we believe we are better positioned today than last quarter, we want to continue to be cognizant of our existing shareholders interest as well. We have been under no pressure to repay TARP from anyone. So in some, we intend to repay our TARP capital as soon as its prudent to do so.
Let me turn the presentation back over to Tim, for a review of credit trends. Tim?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Slide #24 provides an overview of our credit quality trends. As you have heard, we continue to make substantial progress across all of our credit metrics. While the Franklin transaction impact was significant and now allows us to report credi
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Slide #24 provides an overview of our credit quality trends. As you have heard, we continue to make substantial progress across all of our credit metrics. While the Franklin transaction impact was significant and now allows us to report credit metrics on a comparable basis with our peers, the improvement from our ongoing operations is equally important and also sustainable.
The reduction in nonperforming assets and nonperforming loans in the second quarter, excluding Franklin was consistent with first quarter results. We expect to see a continuation of the trend in the coming quarters and I will review some of the specifics on the upcoming slide.
Our criticized loan levels also continued to decline with improvement noted across all of our business segments. The net charge-off ratio associated with our ongoing operations showed solid improvement and we continue to actively manage our late-stage delinquency rate down over time. Importantly, both the charge-off and delinquency trends are evident across all of our portfolio segments.
Our allowance for credit losses ratio declined from 4.14% to 3.9%, but the coverage ratios for both nonaccruing loans and nonperforming assets improved. The coverage ratio associated with criticized assets also improved from the prior quarter. The criticized assets measurement includes commercial criticized loans, consumer over 60-day pass due loans and OREO.
We use this measurement internally and it provides an additional level of granularity and transparency, and our allowance for credit losses coverage, and only looking at the nonaccrual coverage ratios. We continue to feel very comfortable with our reserve level in the context of our portfolio and the market environment.
From an overall portfolio standpoint we continue to see planned reductions in our commercial real estate portfolio, and the C&I portfolio that held steady for the quarter. Within the commercial real estate portfolio, we saw very positive performance from our core portfolio.
The core portfolio remained constant in terms of both portfolio level and asset quality metrics. We had no material change in the core portfolio over the past six months. While we have moved some balances from noncore to core based on our ability to expand the relationships, but loans originally defined as core remain.
The home equity and residential mortgage portfolios remained relatively unchanged in the quarter, but we had a very strong quarter in the auto finance business. As you know, we feel very comfortable with the high-quality focus of this business and the credit quality characteristics, including an average FICO score of 770, end returns on the quarterly production were very strong.
Slide #25 provides a graphical presentation of the nonaccrual loan and nonperforming asset trends on the left side of the slide and the nonaccrual loan inflow on the right side. As we have discussed over the past couple of quarters, the substantial decline in nonaccrual loan inflow is perhaps the most important measurement when assessing the future trends in the portfolio.
Turning to Slide #26, we can review the entire nonperforming asset flow analysis. Of the total decline in nonperforming assets, less than half was related to the Franklin transaction. The drivers of the reduction were charge-offs and loan payments. Importantly, the rate of decline in nonperforming assets accelerated this quarter due to the lower inflow of new NPAs.
Slide #27 continues our disclosure around the level of criticized commercial loans. We saw lower level of inflow during the quarter and just as importantly, we saw a substantially higher level of upgrades into our past categories. We have a very focused upgrade process indicating that these borrowers have established a level of profitability and capital position meriting the change.
As with the nonperforming asset trends we are confident that the declining trend is sustainable in future periods. In summary, the decrease flow of loans into the criticized category is a quantitative indicator that there has been a positive sustainable change in the asset quality trends in the portfolio.
Slide #28 demonstrates the improved credit quality associated with the consumer portfolios. Declining trends are evident across all of our portfolios in both the 30-plus and 90-plus days past due categories. The decline in the over 30-day past due loans has been steady since the second quarter of 2009, indicating that is not simply seasonality or a timing issue. All of the sub-segments reflect the same trend, although to different degrees.
The 90-day past due loans are comprised, primarily of real estate secured loans that have been written down to a realizable value. While the trend is positive, both the level of delinquencies and losses in the consumer portfolio secured by real estate remain at higher than acceptable levels. We continue to originate home equity and residential mortgages in our footprint with the focus on a total financial services relationship.
Origination levels and quality metrics are included in the slide deck appendix. The auto finance portfolio continued to show positive trends even on a lagged analysis basis. We have substantial detail in the appendix to the slide deck regarding the ongoing positive performance trends in the auto portfolio.
While our markets continue to be impacted by the adverse economic conditions, the declining delinquency rate shown here represents some tangible evidence of improvement.
Turning to Slide #29, the commercial net charge-offs on the left side of the slide show a generally declining trend since the second quarter of 2009, with the exception of the outsized fourth quarter that included a number of individual significant size relationships as previously discussed.
Also, of note, recoveries in our C&I portfolio for the second quarter were 50% higher than in the first quarter. While it is too early to call this a trend, we fully expect to recognize increased recoveries in the coming quarters.
The second quarter results were consistent with our expectations based on our active portfolio management strategies. Given the trends in nonaccrual and criticized loans discussed earlier, we are confident our improvement is sustainable.
The graph on the right side of the slide shows consumer loan charge-off trends. As you recall, the third quarter of 2009 included a nonperforming residential loan sale as well as the $32 million loss associated with the policy change to accelerate the timing of loss recognition. In subsequent quarters, we have maintained our proactive loss recognition policies, including aggressive actions on bankrupt borrowers.
Were pleased that the total consumer net charge-off ratio in the 2010 first quarter was down slightly and the second quarter results reflected an additional decline, excluding the impact of the Franklin transaction. Combined with the declining delinquency rates noted earlier, we are confident our consumer portfolio will continue to perform within our expectations in the coming quarters.
Turning to Slide #30, Id like to reemphasis the level of our allowance for credit losses and resulting coverage ratios. In the second quarter and excluding the impact from the Franklin transaction, net charge-offs exceeded provision expense by $86 million.
This resulted in allowance for credit loss level of $1.4 billion and a resulting ratio to total loans of 3.9%. Despite the decline, as shown on the right side of the slide, our coverage of nonaccrual loans increased from 87% to 120%. However, we believe well compare favorably to our peers.
The level is prudent given the continued challenges in the economic environment combined with some of the positive asset quality trends just discussed. We remain committed to maintaining our appropriate level of reserve for our portfolio in the economic environment.
Let me turn this presentation back to Steve.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: So five more slides to recap our current thinking regarding the impact of recent regulatory changes on slide #31, which reflects where we expect to see the impacts.The Federal Reserve recently amended Reg E to prohibit charging overdrafts for ATM or one
componenttext:
So five more slides to recap our current thinking regarding the impact of recent regulatory changes on slide #31, which reflects where we expect to see the impacts.
The Federal Reserve recently amended Reg E to prohibit charging overdrafts for ATM or one-time debit card transaction unless the customer opts in. Our overdraft charges or NSF/OD for sure is a major source of fee income for us and for other banks, for Huntington fee is right about $90 million a year.
Our basic strategy is to mitigate the potential impact by reaching out to customers and alerting them that we can no longer offer such overdrafts unless they opt into our overdraft service.
To-date, our results are surpassing our expectations, and according to a recent survey our opting percentages are higher than most of our peers. At this point over 20% of all customers have opted in, and for those customers that avail themselves to this service the most, the opting rate is nearly 50%. While we know some customers will not opt in at first, over time we believe some will realize that theyve not kept a valuable service and well then opt in.
With the recently passed Dodd-Frank Act, while its complex as it relates to how this legislation and subsequent rulemaking will impact our company, at this time we believe there are two meaningful areas which weve highlighted; interchange fees and the eventual inability to include trust preferred capitals component of regulatory capital.
Now, our annual interchange fee is right about $90 million per year. Most of our fee is what is referred to as signature-based; that is, customer signs an authorization to check out spend, much like a credit card.
The act gives the Federal Reserve and no longer the banks or system owners the ability to set the interchange rate, which we charge margins for the use of debit cards. And what the ultimate impact would be cannot be estimated at this time.
Well have to wait for the Federal Reserve action or may take many months, proposals, debate and then rulemaking. I only wanted to mention today the annual revenue at risk. We believe a fraction and may be a small fraction related revenue will eventually be impacted.
With regard to trust preferred securities (inaudible) $570 million outstanding and if disallowed would reduce the regulatory Tier 1 capital by about 1.34%. There is a three-year phase-in beginning January 1, 2013, so there is plenty of time to strategize our capital structure around this new legislation. We do not believe this is a significant issue for Huntington.
Slide #32 shows various return on asset outcomes given a range of net charge-off assumptions and a pre-tax pre-provision income level equal to this quarters $270 million, about which is where we are today.
We take the $270 million, subtract the intangible amortization expense of $15 million, as its excluded from our pretax pre-provision income calculation, we then provide a range of analyzed net charge-offs from 35 bps to 55 bps, and while we are not yet ready to specify a normalized targeted net charge-off ratio range or what that should be, this range is within certain 10-year and 3-year historical ranges.
We have not considered 2007 for this purpose, as it included a large Franklin charge, which will not recur. We use these net charge-off assumptions as a proxy for the loss provision expense. Subtracting this, this produces a pre-tax income range to which we apply a 30% income tax rate to develop a range of net incomes and calculate the ROI off of that. So we believe weve got 110 to 120 ROA of the 270 pre-tax pre-provision.
Turning to Slide #33, let me outline our financial performance expectations for the second half of the year. With regard to the economy and interest rates we see no meaningful change. Were not expecting a double dip, but we do believe it doesnt take longer for the economy to recover than we did just 90 days ago.
We anticipate second half pre-tax pre-provision income levels will be in line with second quarter reported performance. NIM is expected to approximate debt of the first half of the year. We expect modest growth in C&I and continued strong growth in automobile loans.
CRE loans will continue to decline with home equity and residential mortgages remaining relatively flat. We can see an increase in investment securities as excess cash comes from strong core deposit growth needing to be deployed.
Fee revenue in the second half is expected to be mixed with certain fee income activities getting a lift from the continued rollout of strategic initiatives offset by lower mortgage banking income, as well as service charge income due to the implementation of Reg E.
Expenses also should be relatively stable with increases due to continued implementation of strategic initiatives. Growth in expenses is expected to be mostly offset by lower loan, Franklin portfolio of servicing and monitoring expenses, as well as a general decline in credit monitoring related expenses as nonperforming assets continued to decline.
Charge-offs and provision expenses are anticipated to be generally in line with the second quarter levels, excluding any Franklin impacts. In some, this should translate into revenue and earnings improvement from the second quarter.
Slide #34, before wrapping up, I wanted to remind you of our 2010 objectives. Shown on the slide, we believe they are well understood by every colleague and thats what were working towards for our execution and delivery. In todays presentation, we specifically speak to the second half of the year.
In closing, Id like to remind you of these 2010 objectives. They are essentially the same as they have been through the first quarter and first half. Our balance sheet is getting strong, currently the strongest in recent memory. Our capital levels are sufficient, getting stronger with each profitable quarter. Were substantially improving underlying credit quality trends, which have now been augmented by our decision on Franklin and thats positioning us for a credit quality performance that is better than peers.
Underlying earnings and profitability are growing. We continue to see increased opportunities and focusing a great deal of attention on growing revenue. This is supported by our making investments to grow key fee businesses. While the environment is challenging, were committed to continuing our move to higher levels of performance and improved execution. Were clearly on the move.
So thats it. Thanks for your interest. Operator, well now take questions.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brian, this is Don. As far as the assets, we did provide in our guidance that we expected the pre-tax pre-provision that will be generally in line with the second quarter or quarter results of $270.5 million, but we havent given an updated number for $
componenttext: Brian, this is Don. As far as the assets, we did provide in our guidance that we expected the pre-tax pre-provision that will be generally in line with the second quarter or quarter results of $270.5 million, but we havent given an updated number for $275 million. We try to usually shy away from giving specificity like that in our guidance. We think with the statements that were making, it really puts us in that range that we had communicated before. So we havent made any additional plans to update that $275 million outlook.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, I apologize if I missed a middle window of the call, but just last quarter and the quarter before that you guys had given some helpful color just out talking to clients, what are they saying about wanting to borrow and de-lever up, do your customer
componenttext: Again, I apologize if I missed a middle window of the call, but just last quarter and the quarter before that you guys had given some helpful color just out talking to clients, what are they saying about wanting to borrow and de-lever up, do your customers feel better or worse about the world, right now?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say marginally worse Brian, events in Europe, Gulf, just general lack of confidence, and ongoing sort of macro agendas around cap and trade, and taxes. There is a lot on the move so to speak, and other issues and so it feels a little softer today
componenttext: I would say marginally worse Brian, events in Europe, Gulf, just general lack of confidence, and ongoing sort of macro agendas around cap and trade, and taxes. There is a lot on the move so to speak, and other issues and so it feels a little softer today than I would have said 90 days ago, and thats a generally shared sentiment. So the expectation is continued de-leveraging on both the consumer and business front.

componenttext: Hi, guys. componenttext: Well, we have been working through our private label CMO. Its a little bit in the investment portfolio where weve seen little pockets of risk in different portfolios that have been fairly modest in the scheme of the commercial real estate where weve been working, as well continue to work those. They havent been big enough to bring them to your attention or others attention. So, were on the back side of these de-risking strategies from where we were a year and half ago, but theres still more we want to do.

componenttext: As far as the expenses, we talked a little bit about the charge-offs that were incurred this quarter, absent or prior to the transfer to held-for-sale and that was about $4.5 million and weve been incurring somewhere in the $8 million to $9 million per quarter type of expenses associated with servicing and other support there. A big chunk of those will go away in the third quarter. We do have a small portfolio of seconds well require to continue to have servicing expenses attached to that, but we will see some fairly significant reductions there.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: You highlighted a big spike in the upgrades from the criticized budget and tax rate, can you talk in a way youre seeing in your market thats driving that, thats giving you confidence that that trend could continue in the second half despite some
componenttext: You highlighted a big spike in the upgrades from the criticized budget and tax rate, can you talk in a way youre seeing in your market thats driving that, thats giving you confidence that that trend could continue in the second half despite some greater caution in the market today?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, some of that was perhaps more a conservative posture and Ill point that out, not making sure we had year-end statements before we do upgrades, not using some interims in the second half of last year, Dave. Generally, were very pleased having n
componenttext:
Well, some of that was perhaps more a conservative posture and Ill point that out, not making sure we had year-end statements before we do upgrades, not using some interims in the second half of last year, Dave. Generally, were very pleased having now gotten through a fiscal reporting period at the quality of the book and I would say thats especially true related to the core real estate. Weve had a very stable book for the first six months, even more so than we expected at year-end, so, increasing confidence.
What were seeing and what we think is going to continue is that this deleveraging and the severity of the correction eliminating perhaps some of the competition for some of our customers has put them in a much more stable environment than they might have been a year ago and stable to improving. Not uncommon to hear that on the manufacturing front and distribution front anyway that very good years so far this year and outlook for a good year. So, it feels like the worst is clearly behind us and we think because of the efforts last year that identified problems and deal with them, that we frankly have gotten well ahead of it.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just one more quick one on the margin. If I can just drill down on to that slide 18 real quick on the CD cost. Don you mentioned that one more quarter your higher rate CD is maturing. Given how high the average cost of CDs was during the quarter, it seems
componenttext: Just one more quick one on the margin. If I can just drill down on to that slide 18 real quick on the CD cost. Don you mentioned that one more quarter your higher rate CD is maturing. Given how high the average cost of CDs was during the quarter, it seems like there is another chunk of high rate CDs maturing at some point, maybe next year, Ill try to cope with the slide. Can you talk about that and where are you repricing CDs as they roll today?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The average go-to rate on our CD book is close to a point and a half and thats because its more of a barbell that we have a group of smaller or shorter say 90-day type of maturities and then we have a group in the two-year to three-year bucket
componenttext: Sure. The average go-to rate on our CD book is close to a point and a half and thats because its more of a barbell that we have a group of smaller or shorter say 90-day type of maturities and then we have a group in the two-year to three-year bucket. So there are some sprinkles throughout the remaining quarters, but the last three to four have really been impactful as far as repricing that book and well continue to see some pricing down here in the third quarter.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the brokerage CD, its completely running off, and in the year, is that Don what you think?
componenttext: In terms of the brokerage CD, its completely running off, and in the year, is that Don what you think?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have run those down dramatically that weve actually maybe even thought about doing a little bit of thought dipping our toe and doing some additional broker deposits if we want to in the third quarter just to test the markets and see what kind
componenttext: Well, we have run those down dramatically that weve actually maybe even thought about doing a little bit of thought dipping our toe and doing some additional broker deposits if we want to in the third quarter just to test the markets and see what kind of rates are available there as well. So, dont be surprised if you see some limited action there as well.

componenttextpreview: And where are those pricing today?
componenttext: And where are those pricing today?

componenttext: Between 90 basis points and 100 basis points for an 18 months to 24 months CD.
