headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks. Can you just talk about reserve release going forward? I think if we exclude Franklin, you provisioned about 60% charge-offs or so. Obviously, NPLs coming down. It seems like the credit trends are getting a lot better. Is this a sustainable pace o
componenttext: Thanks. Can you just talk about reserve release going forward? I think if we exclude Franklin, you provisioned about 60% charge-offs or so. Obviously, NPLs coming down. It seems like the credit trends are getting a lot better. Is this a sustainable pace of or a sustainable ratio of provisioning?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I wouldnt lock into it on a ratio basis, Ken. We do expect to see an improvement in nonperforming and charge-offs in the second half. Were viewing this very dynamically and were trying to stay conservative with it given the economic uncertainties
componenttext: I wouldnt lock into it on a ratio basis, Ken. We do expect to see an improvement in nonperforming and charge-offs in the second half. Were viewing this very dynamically and were trying to stay conservative with it given the economic uncertainties.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I understood. I guess I was just commenting more on the very large reserve at least you had in the quarter, and obviously you built up your reserve pretty substantially in the past year, and that needs to come off at some point. Given your credit tren
componenttext: No, I understood. I guess I was just commenting more on the very large reserve at least you had in the quarter, and obviously you built up your reserve pretty substantially in the past year, and that needs to come off at some point. Given your credit trends are more favorable seemed to a lot of the other firms weve seen, should imply in theory sort of a faster reserve release.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Tim, I think we are, as Steve said, working on this as really dynamic issue for us. Were working at the nonaccrual levels, were also working at the criticized asset levels, all of that is included in our analysis, so where the reserve n
componenttext: Ken, this is Tim, I think we are, as Steve said, working on this as really dynamic issue for us. Were working at the nonaccrual levels, were also working at the criticized asset levels, all of that is included in our analysis, so where the reserve needs to be. So, I dont think we can talk about a 60% of charge-off ratio at all, but what occurs over the course of the next few quarters will be a function of how the asset quality improves and also what the charge-off levels are.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The other question I had was just on the pre-tax, pre-provision number. If we assume mortgage banking goes back to more of a normalized $25 million range and then youve got Reg E, I get that the expenses went down, whatever it is, $8 million or so rela
componenttext: The other question I had was just on the pre-tax, pre-provision number. If we assume mortgage banking goes back to more of a normalized $25 million range and then youve got Reg E, I get that the expenses went down, whatever it is, $8 million or so related to Franklin, but do the strategic initiatives that you guys mentioned in the slide deck fully offset that differential. I mean to keep prepaid at a fairly constant level, or is there something else I am missing?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, no, I dont know if youre missing a lot here, but Id say historically over the last several quarters up until this one we were seeing the net interest income increase in the $10 million to $14 million a quarter type of level. So we would cont
componenttext: Ken, no, I dont know if youre missing a lot here, but Id say historically over the last several quarters up until this one we were seeing the net interest income increase in the $10 million to $14 million a quarter type of level. So we would continue to see net interest income grow throughout quarter-to-quarter. We also are looking toward our strategic initiatives to help drive some of the other key fee income categories and we think the combination of those will offset the shortfalls youve talked about to allow us to get back to a level of pre-tax pre-provision thats in line with that reported 270.5 type of levels from the second quarter.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to follow-up on that. You mentioned the MAX sales management system, when will it be rolled out completely? And I am just wondering too if you can give us some perspective on the size of the strategic business investments youre making and any th
componenttext: I want to follow-up on that. You mentioned the MAX sales management system, when will it be rolled out completely? And I am just wondering too if you can give us some perspective on the size of the strategic business investments youre making and any thoughts or color on the impact in terms of the operating expense level?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: We have rolled that out system wise. So, all of our revenue segments, our product revenue segments, all units within each segment, are now on MAX. And the basic functionality is in good shape. We have some further phase refinements that will go on through
componenttext:
We have rolled that out system wise. So, all of our revenue segments, our product revenue segments, all units within each segment, are now on MAX. And the basic functionality is in good shape. We have some further phase refinements that will go on through up till January, the next phase is August. We are very pleased with the tool, we are very pleased with the acceptance and adoption towards giving us even better, frankly, much better insight on what we are getting of a paper tracking process group wide.
So our sales management and sales disciplines are getting better turn. We can see it in cross-sell ratios or new customers as well as existing portfolio. Learning the coordination of taking referrals to sales is getting better, and well continue to improve certainly throughout this year, I think possibly even and definitely. So were well underway I believe.
Now, a lot of the expenses associated with our initiatives in terms of hiring and things like that, we accelerated, we wanted to get that done in the first half, and Im glad we have. We probably have normal revenue line around this that hopefully will give us the second half lift were looking for. Don, would you want to comment more specifically on the economics?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No. I think thats right, Steve, that we have front end loaded to allow the hiring. You saw the FTE increases that occur here in the second quarter. Youve seen a higher level of marketing cost in the second quarter, and we think they are both good in
componenttext: No. I think thats right, Steve, that we have front end loaded to allow the hiring. You saw the FTE increases that occur here in the second quarter. Youve seen a higher level of marketing cost in the second quarter, and we think they are both good indications of run rate going forward that we will continue to evaluate other initiatives and continue to deploy strategic initiatives that are in our pipeline that I would say that the run rate is fairly reflective of the extent of the expense investments were making at this point.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions on lending, I guess, your thoughts on here regarding GMs over curious to banks to provide credit more, and more particularly, how far field are you willing to go in dollar business in both geographically in terms of credit quality? And then
componenttext: Two questions on lending, I guess, your thoughts on here regarding GMs over curious to banks to provide credit more, and more particularly, how far field are you willing to go in dollar business in both geographically in terms of credit quality? And then beyond that I just wonder where you are in gearing up the equipment finance on the asset-based lending businesses, and kind of where that stands now.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The auto business, Tony, is very much in footprint. Its in average FICO between 760, 770. We review weekly the production and AVO [ph]. Were very cognizant of maintaining an adequate return on that and a very high credit quality. Youve seen the c
componenttext: The auto business, Tony, is very much in footprint. Its in average FICO between 760, 770. We review weekly the production and AVO [ph]. Were very cognizant of maintaining an adequate return on that and a very high credit quality. Youve seen the credit quality, as you get into the debt reflected in the numbers in terms of charge-offs, they are down year-over-year over 100 bps, delinquency looks good. So our indicators are very good on that portfolio. Im sorry what was the second one?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: MSR asset base funding.
componenttext: MSR asset base funding.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: AVO is a start up. Its in a very, very early stage. Were closing deals at this point. Weve got a largely an experience team in place. At this stage, its adequate and they are roughly on track. On the equipment finance, we expand on Board about
componenttext: AVO is a start up. Its in a very, very early stage. Were closing deals at this point. Weve got a largely an experience team in place. At this stage, its adequate and they are roughly on track. On the equipment finance, we expand on Board about 45 days and this impact was seen in our June numbers. Pipeline looks good and well be talking about further gearing that business very soon and making a lot of additional investments including some segments in the second half for the year.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010

componenttext: I dont know that well be expecting that, but previously we said that the DTA will come back throughout the 2011 time period for the most part. That we did recognize was primarily related to the Franklin transaction and so the timing of the rest of it still will probably be over the next six plus quarters.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My first question is on your thoughts on credit quality in your core residential real estate portfolio. Given what sounded like more cautious commentary on the housing market, could you give us some insight on how you are thinking about fu
componenttext: Good afternoon. My first question is on your thoughts on credit quality in your core residential real estate portfolio. Given what sounded like more cautious commentary on the housing market, could you give us some insight on how you are thinking about future delinquency trends in the portfolio? Give us also, if you could, some insight on what you think your re-default rate could climb to in your portfolio of modified single family loan?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure, on the first side of it, we expect our delinquency trends to continue to be down over time in our residential portfolio. There is, back on slide #27 or #28, where we give you a pretty good view of the overall total consumer drop and back in the appe
componenttext:
Sure, on the first side of it, we expect our delinquency trends to continue to be down over time in our residential portfolio. There is, back on slide #27 or #28, where we give you a pretty good view of the overall total consumer drop and back in the appendix we have slide #10 on the residential portfolio. So we expect to see some continued improvement in that portfolio.
I think the second half of your question to the modified loans, our expectation for poor performance continues to be about twice as good as the industry as a whole. So much of the industry language around that is at about a 50% re-defaults and right now we are in the 20% range and I dont see a material change in that coming at us.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: My follow-up question is in regards to your guidance for modest loan growth at C&I. A lot of your peers are still seeing a fairly tepid environment for C&I origination. I was wondering if you could tell us what youre doing differently and how your pric
componenttext: My follow-up question is in regards to your guidance for modest loan growth at C&I. A lot of your peers are still seeing a fairly tepid environment for C&I origination. I was wondering if you could tell us what youre doing differently and how your pricing compares with in the marketplace?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, Erika, its hard to respond to what were doing differently, because we dont have a lot of insight into other organizations. We do see some cost initiatives going on in certain banks, so that may in part be impacting and giving us competitive
componenttext:
Well, Erika, its hard to respond to what were doing differently, because we dont have a lot of insight into other organizations. We do see some cost initiatives going on in certain banks, so that may in part be impacting and giving us competitive advantage at least for the moment.
In terms of pricing, we put very good disciplines and reporting in place. As mentioned earlier, we look at auto pricing weekly. We do the same on, frankly, all of our assets, and so were very cognizant of our pricing and the risk return in a dynamic fashion. We dont see that materially changing, in certain geographies a little more pressure than others, in some geographies, theres no pressure. So I dont expect that to materially change in the second half.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, good afternoon. Don, you mentioned the potential for raising common equity, surrounding or in connection with the TARP repayment. Do you think should that be the case youd also look to maybe address that trust preferred capital legislation and
componenttext: Thanks, good afternoon. Don, you mentioned the potential for raising common equity, surrounding or in connection with the TARP repayment. Do you think should that be the case youd also look to maybe address that trust preferred capital legislation and maybe raise a little bit more common equity to take that into consideration, or would you really look to use that full three-year phase-in period and see what happens?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, were not in any big hurry to do really either. I guess as far as the trust preferred, we probably would want to evaluate that full three-year phase time period as far as looking at what the capital implications would be that or have been back in
componenttext:
Terry, were not in any big hurry to do really either. I guess as far as the trust preferred, we probably would want to evaluate that full three-year phase time period as far as looking at what the capital implications would be that or have been back in a position where were having capital accretive earnings.
We would like to continue to maintain that and so hopefully, we could utilize that to offset the re-designation of those TARPs as Tier 2 capital as opposed to Tier 1. The common equity issuance, were just being in connection with any TARP repayment and the timing of which we arent certain on yet.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, as we see a lot going to happen over the span of three years, so we have no contemplation of dealing with TARPs in the context of that capital at this point.
componenttext: Terry, as we see a lot going to happen over the span of three years, so we have no contemplation of dealing with TARPs in the context of that capital at this point.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. My name is Christopher, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Huntington Bancshares Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Gould, you may begin you
componenttext: Good afternoon. My name is Christopher, and I will be your conference operator today. At this time, I would like to welcome everyone to the Huntington Bancshares Second Quarter Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] Mr. Gould, you may begin your conference.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Christopher, and welcome, everybody. I'm Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides we will be reviewing can be found on our website, huntington.com. This call is being recorded and will be available as a reb
componenttext:
Thank you, Christopher, and welcome, everybody. I'm Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides we will be reviewing can be found on our website, huntington.com. This call is being recorded and will be available as a rebroadcast starting about one hour from the close of the call. Please call the Investor Relations department at (614) 480-5676 for more information on how to access these recordings for playback or should have difficulty getting a copy of the slides.
Slides 2, 3 and 4 in your deck note several aspects of the basis of today's presentation. I encourage you to read these, but let me point out one key disclosure. This presentation contains both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures, and where we believe it helpful to understanding Huntingtons results of operations or financial position. Where non-GAAP financial measures are used, the comparable GAAP financial measure, as well as the reconciliation to the comparable GAAP financial measure, can be found in the slide presentation, in its appendix, in the press release, in the quarterly financial review supplement to today's earnings press release, or in the related Form 8-K filed later today. All of these can be found on our website.
Turning to Slide 5, todays discussion, including the Q&A period, may contain forward-looking statements. Such statements are based on information and assumptions available at this time and are subject to changes, risks and uncertainties, which may cause actual results to differ materially. We assume no obligation to update such statements. For a complete discussion of risks and uncertainties, please refer to this slide and material filed with the SEC, including our most recent Forms 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K.
Now turning to today's presentation. As noted on Slide 6, participating today are Steve Steinour, Chairman and Chief Executive Officer; Don Kimble, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Tim Barber, Senior Vice President of Credit Risk Management. Also present, and by way of introduction, is Todd Beekman, who recently joined us as Assistant Director of Investor Relations. He was formerly with Fidelity Management and Research in Boston, where he was an analyst, including several years as a regional bank analyst. Many of you, I know, know Todd. We look forward to his contribution to our IR effort. Let's get started now by turning to Slide 7. Steve?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome, everyone. I'll begin with a review of the second quarter performance highlights. After my overview, Don will detail how Franklin impacted our numbers and then follow with his usual overview of our financial performance. Tim will provide an update
componenttext:
Welcome, everyone. I'll begin with a review of the second quarter performance highlights. After my overview, Don will detail how Franklin impacted our numbers and then follow with his usual overview of our financial performance. Tim will provide an update on credit. I will then return with a discussion of the impact of recent regulatory changes and 2010 outlook comments.
While we will provide the detail in a moment, I want to point out a couple of the key achievements. Overall, we are very pleased with the second quarter performance. We reported a higher profit than last quarter. We saw a 3% linked-quarter growth in revenue, even after excluding a $14.2 million increase in MSR valuation. Our capital ratios meaningfully improved during the quarter. And as expected, we saw significant declines in nonperforming assets inflows -- as inflows of new NPAs in criticized assets continued to fall.
Our period-end nonaccruing loan reserve coverage ratio jumped to 120% from 87%. So in sum, another meaningful step forward, moving Huntington to stronger financial performance. At the end of the quarter, we transferred all of our Franklin loans to held-for-sale, and subsequent to quarter end, we sold $274 million of this exposure. This had a significant impact on second quarter performance, as it resulted in a $75.5 million charge-off and also $75.5 million of provision expense, a negative $0.07 per share. 
There was another $4.5 million in net charge-offs and provision expense associated with Franklin in the quarter, in the second quarter, prior to the transfer in the held-for-sale. Don will detail all of this for you later in this presentation. It's important to understand that this transfer into held-for-sale and subsequent sale was a very positive development. 
Let's begin a more detailed presentation. Turning to Slide 8, we reported net income of $48.8 million or $0.03 per share. This was a significant achievement. The drivers were substantially improved credit quality and higher pretax pre-provision income. We believe these trends will continue. Our pretax pre-provision income was $270.5 million, a 7% improvement from the first quarter and an 18% improvement from a year earlier.
This represented our sixth consecutive quarterly improvement. The primary driver was a 5% link-quarter increase in revenue, reflecting 2% growth in fully taxable equivalent net interest income and a 12% increase in noninterest income. This was partially offset by a 4% link-quarter increase in noninterest expense. The growth in fully taxable equivalent net interest income reflected modest growth in average total loans. We saw very strong growth in average automobile loans and leases, up 9%, as we continued to take advantage of competitive dislocations and benefited from strategic initiatives to expand our in-franchise footprint. 
Average residential mortgages grew 3%. Partially offsetting these increases were a 4% decline in average commercial real estate loans as we continued to reduce net exposure. Our average commercial and industrial loans declined slightly. Period-end C&I loans were up 1% in the end of March or 3% on the accruing portfolio.
Utilization rates remained historically low and relatively unchanged. So this reflects a combination of several factors, including: few opportunities for companies to expand, given the weak economy; companies continuing to build strong cash positions; and a general lack of confidence that is postponing investment decisions. 
Average total investment securities increased 3% as we continued to deploy funds from our strong growth in core deposits. Our net interest margin was 3.46%, down a basis point, of which six basis points related to Franklin loans. 
Noninterest income increased 12%, driven mostly by a $14.2 million increase in MSR valuations, primarily reflecting lowered prepayment assumptions, though we also benefited from a 34% increase in mortgage originations, which contributed a $6.2 million increase in origination and secondary marketing income.
Noninterest income also benefited from an increase in seasonal service charges on deposit accounts. The increase in expenses reflected our continued investment in growth. The real highlight for the quarter was continued significant improvement in credit quality. This improvement reflects clearly the benefit of last year's focused actions to address credit-related problems. We anticipate continued improvement over the second half of this year. On a link-quarter basis, nonperforming assets declined 17% and we saw a 28% decrease in new nonperforming assets.
We also saw an 8% decline in newly identified criticized commercial loans. While reported net charge-offs increased for the prior quarter, excluding Franklin-related net charge-offs that were down 12%, after also adjusting the prior-period Franklin-related net charge-offs. 
Our provision for credit losses was $193.4 million or $117.9 million, excluding the $75.5 million related to Franklin. Both 30- and 90-day delinquencies continued to decline. 
Turning to Slide 9, our period-end allowance for credit losses as a percentage of total loans and leases declined to 3.9%. Importantly, and reflecting substantial improvement in credit quality trends, our nonaccrual loans coverage ratio jumped to 120% from 87%.
Our capital position is solid, with increases in all of our capital ratios. Our regulatory Tier 1 and total risk-based capital ratios are $2.8 and $2 billion above well-capitalized regulatory thresholds. 
Tangible common equity ratio improved 16 bps to 6.12%, and our Tier 1 common risk-based capital ratio improved 51 bps to 7.04%. 
Lastly, our liquidity position remained strong. We saw a 6% annualized core deposit growth with a period-end loan-to-deposit ratio of 93%.
As shown on Slide 10, we continued to move forward with the implementation strategic initiatives designed to grow future revenue. These include the hiring or appointment of new key executives in revenue-generating businesses. In our Commercial Banking segment, this included a new Director of Commercial Banking in central Ohio, a new regional president in the greater Cleveland area and a new president of our Equipment Finance Group. In our Private Financial Group, this included a new president of Unified Fund Services, a new chief operating officer for Huntington Insurance and hiring a new team of trust and private bankers in Dayton, Ohio. 
We also made progress in expanding and upgrading our distribution capabilities. In our Retail and Business Banking segment, we've begun the rebranding and refurbishing of banking offices and initiated in-store and retirement center expansion.
Within PFG, we opened a new office in Wheeling, West Virginia, and a family office in Columbus devoted to assisting high net worth families with managing and preserving generational wealth. 
In support of our initiative to improve cross-sell performance, we launched the first phase of our sales force referral automation system, called MAX. And weve kicked off a strategic plan refresh looking out over the next three years. Each of these initiatives is specifically targeted to grow revenues. The appendix has slides showing all the other initiatives since the first quarter of 2009. We're very excited about the cumulative impact and the opportunities these initiatives represent. 
Turning to Slide 11. Its important to understand Franklin's impact on the quarter as well our rationale for this action. As I noted earlier, at the end of the quarter, we transferred all of our Franklin-related loans to held-for-sale, resulting in a $75.5 million net charge-off. One contributing factor to higher bank stocks valuation is a demonstrated ability to consistently deliver credit quality performance that is better than peers. That's your [ph] (0:13:24) objective and what we want to be known for. 
And as related to Franklin since our restructuring in early 2009, this portfolio has performed as expected, and we were prepared to hold these loans through maturity. However, a negative side effect to retaining these loans has been poorer relative credit quality performance metrics. A confluence of second quarter events gave us the opportunity to essentially bring this relationship to a close by moving these loans into held-for-sale. As the quarter progressed, we saw a renewed buyer interest in distressed debt. And this was the positive. In contrast, we saw an economic outlook turn more uncertain. Further, the expiration of tax credit for home purchases and indications that Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac might accelerate home foreclosures and sales of OREOs raised concern that residential real estate prices could be under pressure over time, which would lower the value of the collateral supporting these loans.
So later in the quarter, we made the decision to move these loans to held-for-sale. This resulted in the $75.5 million of charge-offs, which was disappointing on the one hand. However, I'm pleased to report that on July 20, we sold $274 million of the Franklin-related residential mortgages. Importantly, given today's much stronger balance sheet and earnings performance, we were able to absorb the related charge-offs but still report growth in earnings and a higher capital ratios.
This sale adds to overall future financial performance as we reinvest the proceeds and no longer have to absorb related portfolio servicing and other support costs. And it more quickly moves us to attain our objective of better-than-peer credit quality performance metrics. Let me turn the presentation over to Don to review the details.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. The second column on Slide 12 details the impact of the transfer of the Franklin-related loans to held-for-sale. The third column shows the other Franklin-related net charge-offs, that is, those that occurred during the quarter prior to the
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. The second column on Slide 12 details the impact of the transfer of the Franklin-related loans to held-for-sale. The third column shows the other Franklin-related net charge-offs, that is, those that occurred during the quarter prior to the transfer to held-for-sale. The last column shows the impact from excluding these Franklin-related items. Focusing on the second column, as of June 30, $398 million of Franklin-related loans were charged down to $323 million and transferred to held-for-sale. This resulted in $75.5 million of charge-offs and related provision expense. $14.7 million of the charge-offs were related to Franklin-related home equity loans and $60.8 million of Franklin-related residential mortgages. When adding in the other $4.5 million of Franklin-related net charge-offs, total Franklin net charge-offs in the quarter were $80 million. Net charge-offs as reported and as adjusted to excluded Franklin-related net charge-offs are shown on this slide. For additional detail and a reconciliation of the impact of the Franklin issues on the current as well as prior quarters for all credit-related metrics, please refer to the Franklin reconciliation slide in the appendix.
As Steve noted earlier, the sale of the residential real estate loans was closed on Tuesday, which reduced our NPAs by $225 million. This would have reduced our NPA ratio from 4.24% to 3.65%. 
Turning to Slide 13, our net income for the second quarter was $48.8 million or $0.03 per share. The impact of our transfer to Franklin loans to held-for-sale is our one significant item impacting the quarters results. As discussed earlier, we recognized a $75.5 million or $0.07 per share provision expense related to the transfer. This impact is net of estimated selling costs. 
Slide 14 provides a summary of our quarterly earnings trends. Many of the performance metrics will be discussed later in the presentation. Let's move on. On Slide 15, we provide an overview of our pretax pre-provision income performance. We continue to believe this metric is useful in assessing underlying operating performance. We calculated this metric by starting with pretax earnings and then excluding three items: provision for credit losses, security gains and losses and amortization of intangibles.
We also adjusted certain significant items, where applicable. On this basis, our pretax pre-provision income for the second quarter was $270 million, up $18 million or 7% from last quarter and 18% higher than a year ago. 
Slide 16 depicts the trends of our net interest income and margin. During the second quarter, our fully tax-equivalent net interest income increased by $6 million, reflecting a one basis point decline in our net interest margin of 3.46% and a $0.3 billion increase to our average earning asset base. The margin change reflected several items: First was the impact of our deposit mix and pricing changes. The mix shift from time deposits to more transaction-based core deposits not only reduces our costs but also produces a more stable deposit base for us as well. 
Offsetting this positive impact was a $6.8 million or six basis point reduction in the margin coming from the Franklin-related loans. During this first quarter, we received more payments on loans that had been already reduced to a zero balance, resulting in additional interest income. These payments flowed significantly in the second quarter. Other items impacted the quarter included lower interest income on our interest rate derivatives, in part due to the changes in the interest rate environment. Also, the day count negatively impacted the second quarter margin. 
Going forward, we expect some of the same trends with the Franklin-related sale having a slight reduction to the margins but a positive impact to the bottom line after considering the servicing cost previously incurred.
Continuing on to Slide 17, we showed a change in our deposit mix over the last five quarters. This shift, from 45% of the deposits in time and non-core funds to 29%, has improved the margin by 22 basis points. This mix will also have some impact on the third quarter from the expiration of the TAGP program. We saw $100 million dollars move from transaction accounts to other products, including sweep accounts and short-term liabilities. We also saw approximately $600 million of reductions to our deposits as a result of requirements for FDIC coverage. Overall, this performance was in line or better than our expectations. We also have one quarter left of higher-price time deposits running off. 
Turning to Slide 18, we continued to generate strong core deposit growth. Total core deposits grew at an annualized 6% rate, despite a $0.8 billion decline in average core loan deposits. 
Slide 19 shows the trends on our Loan and Lease portfolio. This was the first quarter in the last six that we've actually shown loan growth. Total commercial loans were down $0.4 billion or 2%. The decline reflected the anticipated decline in commercial real estate balances. The $0.1 billion decline in C&I loans reflected the continued deleveraging from our commercial customers. However, we did experience $147 million increase in period-end balances from March 31 to June 30. 
Total consumer loans were up $0.5 billion or 3% from the prior quarter. The $0.4 billion increase in average automobile loans and leases reflected record originations of over $900 million this past quarter. These originations continue to reflect very high credit quality and reasonable returns. 
Slide 20 shows the trends in our noninterest income categories. Our noninterest income increased by $28.8 million from the prior quarter. Our mortgage banking revenues increased by $20.5 million, reflecting a $14 million increase to the net MSR hedging income. This increase reflected a reduction to the underlying prepayment assumptions for MC MSR [ph] (0:21:12) asset. These prepayment assumptions were accelerated throughout 2009 with the expectation that the government programs would increase the refinance activity. We continue to use a third party to assist in valuing the MSR asset and another to help validate the value assigned. Deposit service charges were up $6.6 million and electronic banking revenues were up $3 million, both reflecting normal seasonal trends. 
The next slide is a summary of our expense trends. Total expenses were up $15.7 million from the prior quarter. This reflected an $11.2 million or 6% increase in personnel costs. This increase was due to a 4% increase in staffing levels, attributed to strategic initiatives implemented over the last two quarters; the full quarter impact of merit increases awarded late in the first quarter; and the reinstatement of the company's 401(k) plan matching contribution. 
Marketing costs were up $6.5 million, attributed to the brand advertising campaign launched in the second quarter. Other expenses were up $2.8 million, including a $5.4 million increase on costs related to reps and warranties on mortgage loan sales. $4 million of this increase was attributed to an increase to the reserve for this liability, as were using a more forward-looking estimate, reflecting the increased cost of the current quarter. Offsetting these increases were declines in OREO, with foreclosure expenses as well as seasonal clients and occupancy costs. 
Slide 22 is a summary of our capital trends. The current quarter's profit resulted in an increase to our tangible common equity ratio from 5.96% to 6.12%. But reflecting an even stronger improvement was our regulatory capital ratios. Our Tier 1 common ratio increased to 7.04% from 6.53%, and our Tier 1 ratio increased to 12.47% from 11.97%. These increases not only benefited from the capital accretive earnings but also from a decrease in the total disallowed deferred tax asset for regulatory capital purposes from $390 million at March 31, to $191 million at June 30, as a result of the recognition of the tax impact of the Franklin-related charge-offs. The deferred tax asset realization for regulatory capital purposes improved the ratios by approximately 47 basis points.
Turning to Slide 23, one cannot talk about capital without some mention of our plans to repay our $1.4 billion in TARP capital. We believe that we're better positioned for repayment today. We have strong balance sheet liquidity, and our current regulatory capital is over $2 billion in excess of the existing well-capitalized thresholds. And with another quarter of profitable performance and expectations of continued profitability, we are back to generating capital internally. 
However, and as noted last quarter, we believe there are three factors for consideration before repayment: The first is consistent demonstrated profitable performance with growth in earnings. We believe we're on our way. Again, its only two quarters in a row. The second is evidence of a sustained economic recovery. This outlook turned a little more negative this past quarter, and while we think the economy is stabilizing, it remains fragile. Third, having better clarity on any new regulatory capital thresholds would be helpful. 
While the recently passed Dodd-Frank Wall Street Reform and Consumer Protection Act gave the authority to set these standards, it will be some time before the specific regulations are written. We think our current ratios are above where these new thresholds may eventually be set, but that's not a certainty. 
Based on other banks that have had to raise capital at the time they repaid their TARP, it is likely that we will have to raise capital as well. While we believe we're better positioned today than last quarter, we want to continue to be cognizant of our existing shareholders interest as well. We have been under no pressure to repay TARP from anyone. So in sum, we intend to repay our TARP capital as soon as it's prudent to do so. Let me turn the presentation back over to Tim for a review of credit trends. Tim?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Slide 24 provides an overview of our credit quality trends. As you have heard, we continue to make substantial progress across all of our credit metrics. While the Franklin transaction impact was significant and now allows us to report credit
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Slide 24 provides an overview of our credit quality trends. As you have heard, we continue to make substantial progress across all of our credit metrics. While the Franklin transaction impact was significant and now allows us to report credit metrics on a comparable basis with our peers, the improvement from our ongoing operations is equally important and also sustainable. The reduction in nonperforming assets and nonperforming loans in the second quarter excluding Franklin was consistent with first quarter results. We expect to see a continuation of the trend in the coming quarters, and I will review some of its specifics on an upcoming slides. 
Our criticized loan levels also continued to decline, with improvement noted across all of our business segments. And that charge-off ratio associated with our ongoing operations showed solid improvement, and we continued to actively manage our late-stage delinquency rate down over time. Importantly, both the charge-off and delinquency trends are evident across of all our portfolio segments. Our allowance for credit losses ratio declined from 4.14% to 3.9%, but the coverage ratios for both non-accruing loans and nonperforming assets improved. The coverage ratio associated with criticized assets also improved from the prior quarter. 
The criticized assets measurement includes commercial criticized loans, consumer over-60-day past-due loans and OREO. We use this measurement internally, and it provides an additional level of granularity and transparency in our allowance for credit losses coverage, and only looking at the nonaccrual coverage ratios. We continue to feel very comfortable with our reserve level in the context of our portfolio and the market environment.
From an overall portfolio standpoint, we continued to see planned reductions in our Commercial Real Estate portfolio and a C&I portfolio that held steady for the quarter. Within the Commercial Real Estate portfolio, we saw a very positive performance on our Core portfolio. The Core portfolio remained constant in terms of both portfolio level and asset quality metrics. We have seen no material change in the core portfolio over the past six months. While we have moved some balances from non-core to core, based on our ability to expand the relationships, the loans originally defined as core remain. 
The Home Equity and Residential Mortgage portfolios remained relatively unchanged in the quarter, but we had a very strong quarter in the Auto Finance business. As you know, we feel very comfortable with the high-quality focus of this business and the credit quality characteristics, including an average score FICO score of 770, and returns on the quarterly production were very strong. 
Slide 25 provides a graphic representation of the nonaccrual loan and nonperforming asset trends on the left side of the slide and the nonaccrual loan inflow on right side. As we have discussed over the past couple of quarters, the substantial decline in nonaccrual loan inflow is perhaps the most important measurement when assessing the future trends in the portfolio. 
Turning to Slide 26, we can review the entire nonperforming asset flow analysis. Of the total decline in nonperforming assets, less than half was related to the Franklin transaction. The drivers of the reduction were charge-offs and loan payments. Importantly, the rate of decline in nonperforming assets accelerated this quarter due to the lower inflow of new NPAs. Slide 27 continues our disclosure around the level of criticized commercial loans. We saw a lower level of inflow during the quarter, and just as importantly, we saw a substantially higher level of upgrades into our past categories. We have a very focused upgrade process, indicating that these borrowers have established a level of profitability and capital position meriting the change. As with the nonperforming asset trends, we are confident that the declining trend is sustainable in future periods. 
In summary, the decrease flow of loans into the criticized category is a quantitative indicator that there has been a positive sustainable change in the asset quality trends in the portfolio.
Slide 28 demonstrates the improved credit quality associated with the Consumer portfolios. Declining trends are evident across all of our portfolios in both the 30-plus and 90-plus days past due categories. The decline in the over 30-day past due loans has been steady since the second quarter of 2009, indicating that is not simply seasonality or a timing issue. All of the sub-segments reflect the same trends, although to different degrees. The 90-day past due loans are comprised primarily of real estate secured loans that have been written down to a realizable value. While the trend is positive, both the level of delinquencies and losses in the Consumer portfolio secured by real estate remain at higher-than-acceptable levels. We continue to originate home equity and residential mortgages in our footprint, with a focus on a total financial services relationship. Origination levels and quality metrics are included in the slide deck appendix. 
The Auto Finance portfolio continued to show positive trends, even on a lagged-analysis basis. We have substantial detail in the appendix to the slide deck regarding the ongoing positive performance trends in the auto portfolio. While our markets continue to be impacted by the adverse economic conditions, the declining delinquency rates shown here represent some tangible evidence of improvement. 
Turning to Slide 29, the commercial net charge-offs on the left side of the slide show a generally declining trend since the second quarter of 2009, with the exception of the outsized fourth quarter that included a number of individual significant-size relationships, as previously discussed. Also of note, recoveries in our C&I portfolio for the second quarter were 50% higher than in the first quarter. While it is too early to call this a trend, we fully expect to recognize increased recoveries in the coming quarters. 
The second quarter results were consistent with our expectations based on our active portfolio management strategies. Given the trends in nonaccrual and criticized loans discussed earlier, we are confident our improvement is sustainable. 
The graph on the right side of the slide shows consumer loan charge-off trends. As you recall, the third quarter of 2009 included a nonperforming residential loan sale as well as a $32 million loss associated with a policy change to accelerate the timing of loss recognition. In subsequent quarters, we have maintained our proactive loss recognition policies, including aggressive actions on bankrupt borrowers. We were pleased that the total consumer net charge-off ratio in the 2010 first quarter was down slightly and the second quarter results reflected an additional decline excluding the impact of the Franklin transaction.
Combined with the declining delinquency rates noted earlier, we are confident our Consumer portfolio will continue to perform within our expectations in the coming quarters. 
Turning to Slide 30, I'd like to re-emphasize the level of our allowance for credit losses and resulting coverage ratios. In the second quarter, and excluding the impact from the Franklin transaction, net charge-offs exceeded provision expense by $86 million. This resulted in an allowance for credit loss level of $1.4 billion and a resulting ratio to total loans of 3.9%. Despite the decline, as shown on the right side of the slide, our coverage of nonaccrual loans increased from 87% to 120%, a level we believe will compare favorably to our peers. This level is prudent given the continued challenges in the economic environment, combined with some of the positive asset quality trends just discussed. We remain committed to maintaining an appropriate level of reserve for our portfolio in the economic environment. Let me turn this presentation back to Steve.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just five more slides to recap our current thinking regarding the impact of recent regulatory changes. On Slide 31, this reflects where we expect to see the impacts. The Federal Reserve recently amended Reg E to prohibit charging overdrafts for ATM or a o
componenttext:
Just five more slides to recap our current thinking regarding the impact of recent regulatory changes. On Slide 31, this reflects where we expect to see the impacts. The Federal Reserve recently amended Reg E to prohibit charging overdrafts for ATM or a one-time debit card transaction unless the customer opts in. Our overdraft charges, or NSF/OD for short, is a major source of fee income for us and for other banks. For Huntington, fees run about $90 million a year. 
Our basic strategy is to mitigate the potential impact by reaching out to customers and alerting them that we can no longer offer such overdrafts unless they opt in to our overdraft service. To date, our results are surpassing our expectations, and according to a recent survey, our opt-in percentages are higher than most of our peers. At this point, over 20% of our customers have opted in, and for those customers that avail themselves to this service the most, the opt-in rate is nearly 50%. While we know some customers will not opt in at first, over time, we believe some will realize that theyve not kept a valuable service and will then opt in. 
With the recently passed Dodd-Frank Act is complex -- while its complex as it relates to how this legislation and subsequent rule-making will impact our company, at this time we believe there are two meaningful areas which weve highlighted: interchange fees and the eventual inability to include trust preferred capital as a component of regulatory capital. Now our annual interchange fees run about $90 million per year. And most of our fees are what is referred to as signature-based. That is, the customer signs an authorization at the checkout stand, much like a credit card. 
The Act gives the Federal Reserve and no the longer banks or system owners the ability to set the interchange rate which we charge merchants for the use of debit cards. And what the ultimate impact will be cannot be estimated at this time. Well have to wait for the Federal Reserve action and that is -- or may take many months of proposals, debate, and then rule-making. I only wanted to mention today the annual revenue at risk. We believe a fraction and maybe a small fraction of related revenue will eventually be impacted. 
With regard to Trust Preferred Securities, were currently at $570 million outstanding, and if disallowed, would reduce the regulatory Tier 1 capital by about 1.34%. Theres a three-year phase-in beginning January 1, 2013, so theres plenty of time to strategize our capital structure around this new legislation. We do not believe this is a significant issue for Huntington. 
Slide 32 shows various return on asset outcomes, given a range of net charge-off assumptions and a pretax pre-provision income level equal to this quarter's $270 million, about where -- which is where we are today. We take the $270 million. Subtract the intangible amortization expense of $15 million, as it's excluded from our pretax pre-provision income calculation. We then provide a range of analyzed net charge-off from 35 bps to 55 bps, and while we're not yet ready to specify a normalized targeted net charge-off ratio range, or what that should be, this range is within certain 10- and 3-year historical ranges. We did not consider 2007 for this purpose, as it would have included a large Franklin charge, which will not recur. We use these net charge-off assumptions as a proxy for loan loss provision expense. Subtracting this produces a pretax income range, which would apply a 30% income tax rate to develop a range of net income, and calculate the ROA off of that. So we believe we've got a 110 to 120 ROA off the $270 million pretax pre-provision. 
Turning to Slide 33. Let me outline our financial performance expectations for the second half of the year. With regard to the economy and interest rates, we see no meaningful change. We're not expecting a double dip, but we do believe its now going to take longer for the economy to recover than we did just 90 days ago. We anticipate second half pretax pre-provision income levels will be aligned with second quarter reported performance. 
NIM is expected to approximate debt of the first half of the year. We expect modest growth in C&I and continued strong growth from automobile loans. CRE loans will continue to decline, with home-equity and residential mortgages remaining relatively flat. We can see an increase in investment securities as excess cash comes from strong core deposit growth needing to be deployed. Fee revenue in the second half is expected to be mixed with certain fee income activities given a lift from the continued rollout of strategic initiatives offset by lower mortgage banking income as well as service charge income due to implementation of Reg E. 
Expenses also should be relatively stable, with increases due to the continued implementation of strategic initiatives. Any growth in expenses is expected to be mostly offset by lower loan, Franklin portfolio servicing and monitoring expenses, as well as a general decline in credit-monitoring-related expenses as nonperforming assets continue to decline. Charge-offs and provision expenses are anticipated to be generally aligned with the second quarter levels, excluding any Franklin impacts. In sum, this should translate into revenue and earnings improvement from the second quarter. 
Slide 34. Before I wrap you up, I wanted to remind you of our 2010 objectives shown on this slide. We believe theyre well understood by every colleague, and that's what we're working towards our execution and delivery. In today's presentation, these specifically speak to the second half of the year. 
In closing, I'd like to remind you of these 2010 objectives. They're essentially the same as they have been through the first quarter and first half. Our balance sheet getting strong, currently the strongest in recent memory. Our capital levels are sufficient, getting stronger with each profitable quarter. Were substantially improving underlying credit quality trends, which have now been augmented by our decision on Franklin, and that's positioning us for a credit quality performance that is better than peers. 
Underlying earnings and profitability are growing. We continue to see increased opportunities in focusing a great deal of attention on growing revenue. This is supported by our making investments to grow key fee businesses. While the environment is challenging, we're committed to continuing our move to higher levels of performance and improved execution. We're clearly on the move. 
So that's it. Thanks for your interest. Operator, we'll now take questions.

componenttext: And then, and then again I apologize if I missed it, because I missed a middle window of the call, but just last quarter and the quarter before that, you guys had given some helpful color just out talking to clients. componenttext: I think Id say marginally worse, Brian. Theyre -- events in Europe, Gulf, just general lack of confidence, ongoing sort of macro agendas around cap and trade and taxes. There's a lot on the move, so to speak, and on other issues. And so it feels a little softer today than we wouldve said 90 days ago. And thats a generally shared sentiment, and so the expectation is continued deleveraging in both the consumer and business front.

componenttext: As far as the expenses, we talked a little bit about the charge-offs that were incurred this quarter prior to transfer to held-for-sale, and that was about $4.5 million. And we've been incurring somewhere in the $8 million to $9 million per quarter type of expenses associated with servicing and other support there. And a big chunk of those will go away in the third quarter. We do have a small portfolio of seconds that will require to continue to have servicing expenses attached to that, that we will see some fairly significant reductions there.

componenttext: You highlighted a big spike in the upgrades from the criticized budget to the tax rate. Can you talk about what you're seeing in your markets thats driving that and thats giving you confidence that, that trend could continue in the second half despite some greater caution in the market today?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, some of that was perhaps a more conservative posture, and our point about not -- making sure we had year-end statements before we did upgrades, not using some interims in the second half of last year, Matt. But, generally, we're very pleased at havi
componenttext: Well, some of that was perhaps a more conservative posture, and our point about not -- making sure we had year-end statements before we did upgrades, not using some interims in the second half of last year, Matt. But, generally, we're very pleased at having now gotten through a reporting, a fiscal reporting period, the quality of the book.  And I would say thats especially true related to the core real estate. We've had a very stable book for the first six months. Even more so than we expected at year end. So increasing confidence, and what we think is -- what we're seeing and what we thinking is going to continue, is that deleveraging and the severity of the correction eliminates perhaps some of the competition for some of our customers, has put them in a much more stable environment than they might have been a year ago, and stable to improving. And not uncommon to hear that the -- or in the manufacturing front and distribution front, anyway, that very good years, so far this year and outlook for a good year. So it feels like the worst is clearly behind us, and we think because of the efforts last year to identify problems and deal with them that we, frankly, have gotten well ahead of it.

componenttext: On the margin, if I could just drill down to Slide 18 real quick on the CD cost. Don, you mentioned that you have one more quarter here of higher rate change and maturity. But given how high the average cost of CDs was during the quarter, it seems like there's another chunk of higher-rate CDs maturing at some point, maybe next year, outside the scope of this slide. Can you talk about that and where you're repricing CDs as they roll today?

componenttextpreview: Sure, the average go-to rate on our CD book is close to a point and a half. And thats because it's more of a barbell that we have, a group of smaller, say, 90 -- or shorter, say, 90-day type of maturities.  But then we have a group in the two- to three
componenttext: Sure, the average go-to rate on our CD book is close to a point and a half. And thats because it's more of a barbell that we have, a group of smaller, say, 90 -- or shorter, say, 90-day type of maturities.  But then we have a group in the two- to three-year bucket, so there are some sprinkled throughout the remaining quarters, but the last three to four have really been impactful as far as repricing that book, and we'll continue to see some pricing down here in the third quarter.

componenttext: Well, we have run those down dramatically, but weve actually and maybe even thought about doing a little bit of sort of dipping our toe into doing some additional broker deposits if we want to, here in the third quarter, just to test the markets and see what kind of rates are available there as well. Obviously, NPL coming down, it seems like the credit trends are getting a lot better. Is this a sustainable pace of, or a sustainable ratio of provisioning?

componenttextpreview: I wouldnt lock into it on a ratio basis, Ken, but we do expect to see an improvement in nonperforming and charge-offs in the second half. And I think if you use the ratio, we're viewing this very dynamic when we're trying to stay conservative with it,
componenttext: I wouldnt lock into it on a ratio basis, Ken, but we do expect to see an improvement in nonperforming and charge-offs in the second half. And I think if you use the ratio, we're viewing this very dynamic when we're trying to stay conservative with it, given the economic uncertainties.

componenttext: No, understood. I guess I was just commenting more on the very large reserve release you had in the quarter, and, obviously, youve built up your reserve pretty substantially in the past year. And that needs to come off at some point, and given your credit trends are more favorable, it seems, than a lot of the other firms that weve seen, should imply, in theory, sort of a faster reserve release.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. All right, Ken, its Tim. I think were, as Steve said, working on this as really a dynamic issue for us. Were looking at the nonaccrual levels. We're also looking at the criticized asset levels. All of that is included in our analysis of wher
componenttext: Yes. All right, Ken, its Tim. I think were, as Steve said, working on this as really a dynamic issue for us. Were looking at the nonaccrual levels. We're also looking at the criticized asset levels. All of that is included in our analysis of where the reserve needs to be. So I don't think we can talk about a 60% of charge-off ratio at all. But what occurs over the course of the next few quarters will be a function of how the asset quality improves and also what the charge-off levels are.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now it makes sense. The other question I had, just on the, I guess, the pretax pre-provision number. It seems that if we assume mortgage banking goes back to more of a normalized $25 million range, and then you got Reg E, I get that the expenses go down,
componenttext: Now it makes sense. The other question I had, just on the, I guess, the pretax pre-provision number. It seems that if we assume mortgage banking goes back to more of a normalized $25 million range, and then you got Reg E, I get that the expenses go down, whatever it is, $8 million or so related to Franklin. But did the strategic initiative that you guys mentioned in the slide deck fully offset that differential? I mean, to keep pre-period [ph] (0:51:43) at a fairly constant level? Or is there something else that I'm missing?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, no, I don't know that you're missing a lot here, but Id say historically over the last several quarters up until this one, we were seeing the net interest income increase in the $10 to the $14 million a quarter-type of level, and so we would expec
componenttext: Ken, no, I don't know that you're missing a lot here, but Id say historically over the last several quarters up until this one, we were seeing the net interest income increase in the $10 to the $14 million a quarter-type of level, and so we would expect to continue to see some net interest income growth throughout the quarter-to-quarter. We also are looking toward our strategic initiatives to help drive some of those other key fee income categories, and we think the combination of those will offset the shortfalls you've talked about to allow us to get back to a level of pretax pre-provision thats in line with that reported $270.5 million type of level from the second quarter.

componenttext: I was trying [ph] (0:52:40) to follow-up on that. You mentioned the MAX sales management system. When it will be rolled out completely? And I was just wondering, too, if you could you give us some perspective on the size of the strategic business investments you're making and any thoughts or color on the impact in terms of the operating expense load?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we have rolled that out system-wide, so all of our revenue segments, our product revenue segments, all units within each segment are now on MAX. We have some further -- and the basic functionality is in good shape. We have some further phase refinem
componenttext: Well, we have rolled that out system-wide, so all of our revenue segments, our product revenue segments, all units within each segment are now on MAX. We have some further -- and the basic functionality is in good shape. We have some further phase refinements that will go on through up till January. The next phase is August. We're very pleased with the tool. Were very pleased with the acceptance and adoption tool. Its given us even better, frankly, much better insight than what we were getting off a paper tracking process group-wide. So our sales management and sales disciplines are getting better, Tony, and we can see it in cross-sell ratios or new customers as well as existing portfolio. And the learning, the coordination of taking referrals to sales is getting better and will continue to improve, certainly throughout this year and I think possibly even indefinitely. So we're well underway, I believe. Now a lot of the expenses associated with the initiatives, in terms of hiring and things like that, we accelerated, we wanted to get that into the -- get that done in the first half, and Im glad we have. We probably have a normal revenue lag around this that hopefully will give us the second half lift we're looking for. And, Don, would you want to comment more specifically on any of the economics?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I think that's right, Steve, that we have front-end loaded a lot of the hiring. And you saw the FTE increases that occurred here in the second quarter. You're seeing a higher level of marketing costs in the second quarter, and we think those are both
componenttext: No, I think that's right, Steve, that we have front-end loaded a lot of the hiring. And you saw the FTE increases that occurred here in the second quarter. You're seeing a higher level of marketing costs in the second quarter, and we think those are both good indications of run rate going forward. But we will continue to evaluate other initiatives and continue to deploy strategic initiatives that are in our pipeline. But I'd say that the run rate is fairly reflective of the extent of the expense investments, what we're making at this point.

componenttext: Two questions on the lending, I guess. headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Auto business, Tony, is very much in footprint. Its in an average FICO between 760, 770. We review weekly the production and yields, and we're very cognizant of maintaining an adequate return off that in a very high credit quality. And youre see
componenttext: The Auto business, Tony, is very much in footprint. Its in an average FICO between 760, 770. We review weekly the production and yields, and we're very cognizant of maintaining an adequate return off that in a very high credit quality. And youre seeing the credit quality as you get into the debt reflected in the numbers in terms of charge-offs. So theyre down year-over-year over 100 bps. Delinquency looks good. So our indicators are very good on the portfolio. Im sorry, what was the second question?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: That was on finance, on asset-based lending.
componenttext: That was on finance, on asset-based lending.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: ABL is a startup. Its in a very, very early stage. We're closing deals at this point. We've got a largely an experienced team in place that at this stage is adequate. And then roughly on track. On the equipment finance, Ricks been on board about 45
componenttext: ABL is a startup. Its in a very, very early stage. We're closing deals at this point. We've got a largely an experienced team in place that at this stage is adequate. And then roughly on track. On the equipment finance, Ricks been on board about 45 days, and his impact was seen in our June numbers. Pipeline looks good, and we'll be talking about further gearing that business very soon and making some level of additional investments including some segments in the second half of the year.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Don, one final quick one for you.  And move it backs [ph] (0:57:30) to the remaining $190 million in deferred tax assets. Is it reasonable youd have that back in regulatory capital here by the end of the year?
componenttext: Don, one final quick one for you.  And move it backs [ph] (0:57:30) to the remaining $190 million in deferred tax assets. Is it reasonable youd have that back in regulatory capital here by the end of the year?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don't know that I would be expecting that, but previously weve said that the DTA would come back throughout the 2011 time period for the most part. And the asset we did recognize was primarily related to the Franklin transaction, and so the timing of
componenttext: I don't know that I would be expecting that, but previously weve said that the DTA would come back throughout the 2011 time period for the most part. And the asset we did recognize was primarily related to the Franklin transaction, and so the timing of the rest of it still will probably be over to next six-plus quarters.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Penala from UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Erika Penala from UBS.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: My first question is on your thoughts on credit quality in your core Residential Real Estate portfolio. Given what sounded like more cautious commentary on the housing market, could you give us some insight on how you're thinking about future delinquency
componenttext: My first question is on your thoughts on credit quality in your core Residential Real Estate portfolio. Given what sounded like more cautious commentary on the housing market, could you give us some insight on how you're thinking about future delinquency trends in the portfolio? And give us also, if you could, some insight on what you think your re-default rate could climb to in your portfolio of modified single family loans?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. On the first side of it, we expect our delinquency trends to continue to be down over time in our residential portfolio. Theres back on Slide 27 or 28 we give you a pretty good view of the overall total consumer drop. And back in the appendix we
componenttext: Sure. On the first side of it, we expect our delinquency trends to continue to be down over time in our residential portfolio. Theres back on Slide 27 or 28 we give you a pretty good view of the overall total consumer drop. And back in the appendix we have some slides on the Residential portfolio, specifically. On 10 is the actual slide set. We expect to see some continued improvement in that portfolio. I think the second half of your question relates to the modified loans. And our expectation for core performance continues to be about twice as good as the industry as a whole. So much of the industry language around that is at about a 50% re-default, and right were in the 20% range and don't see a material change in that coming at us.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up question is in regards to your guidance for a modest loan growth in C&I. A lot of your peers are still seeing a fairly tepid environment for C&I originations. And I was wondering if you could tell us what you're doing differently and how
componenttext: And my follow-up question is in regards to your guidance for a modest loan growth in C&I. A lot of your peers are still seeing a fairly tepid environment for C&I originations. And I was wondering if you could tell us what you're doing differently and how your pricing compares with, in the marketplace?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, were -- Erika its hard to respond to what we're doing differently because we dont have a lot of insight into other organizations. We do see some cost initiatives going on in certain banks. So that may in part be impacting and giving us a co
componenttext: Well, were -- Erika its hard to respond to what we're doing differently because we dont have a lot of insight into other organizations. We do see some cost initiatives going on in certain banks. So that may in part be impacting and giving us a competitive advantage, at least for the moment. In terms of pricing, we put very good disciplines and reporting in place. Mentioned earlier, we look at other pricing weekly. We do the same on, frankly, all of our assets. And so we're very cognizant of our pricing and risk return in a dynamic fashion. We don't see that materially changing. In certain geographies, a little more pressure than others. In some geographies, there's no pressure. So I don't expect that to materially change in the second half.

componenttext: Don, you mentioned the potential for raising common equity surrounding or in connection with the TARP repayment. Do you think, should that be the case, you'd also look to maybe address that trust preferred capital legislation and maybe raise a little bit more common equity to take that into consideration? Or would you really look to use that full three-year phase-in period and see what happens?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul 22, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, we're not in any big hurry to do really either. But I guess as the trust preferred, we probably would want to evaluate that full three phase [ph] (1:02:00) time period as far as looking at what the capital applications would be. But we're happy to
componenttext: Terry, we're not in any big hurry to do really either. But I guess as the trust preferred, we probably would want to evaluate that full three phase [ph] (1:02:00) time period as far as looking at what the capital applications would be. But we're happy to be back in a position where were having capital accretive earnings, and wed like to continue to maintain that. And so hopefully we could utilize that to offset the redesignation of those TARPs as Tier 2 capital as opposed to Tier 1. And the common equity issuance would just be in connection with any TARP repayment, and the timing of which we aren't certain on yet.
