You may begin your conference.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chris. And good morning, everybody. I am Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides we will be reviewing can be found on our website, huntington.com. This call is being recorded and will be available as a reb
componenttext:
Thank you, Chris. And good morning, everybody. I am Jay Gould, Director of Investor Relations for Huntington. Copies of the slides we will be reviewing can be found on our website, huntington.com. This call is being recorded and will be available as a rebroadcast starting about one hour from the close of the call. Please call Investor Relations at (614) 480-5676 for more information on how to access these recordings or playback or should have difficulty getting a copy of the slides.
Slides 2, 3 and 4 note several aspects of the basis of today's presentation. I encourage you as always to read these, but let me point out one key disclosure. This presentation contains both GAAP and non-GAAP financial measures, and where we believe is helpful to understanding Huntingtons results of operations or financial position. Where non-GAAP financial measures are used, the comparable GAAP financial measure, as well as the reconciliation to the comparable GAAP financial measure can be found in: The slide presentation; in its appendix; in the press release; in the quarterly financial review supplement to today's earnings press release; or in the related Form 8-K filed later today, all of which can be found on our website.
Turning to Slide 5, todays discussion, including the Q&A period, may contain forward-looking statements. Such statements are based on information and assumptions available at this time and are subject to changes, risks and uncertainties, which may cause actual results to differ materially. We assume no obligation to update such statements. For a complete discussion of risks and uncertainties, please refer to the slides and material filed with the SEC, including our most recent Forms 10-K, 10-Q and 8-K.
Now turning to today's presentation. As noted on Slide 6, participating today are Steve Steinour, Chairman, President and Chief Executive Officer; Don Kimble, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer; and Dan Neumeyer, Senior Executive Vice President and Chief Credit Officer Management. Also present is Mary Navarro, Senior Executive Vice President and Retail and Business Banking Director, and Todd Beekman, Senior Vice President and Assistant Director of Investor Relations. Let's get started and turn to Slide #7. Steve, take it away.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome, everyone. I'll begin with a review of the third quarter performance highlights. After my overview, Don will follow with his usual overview of our financial performance. Dan will provide an update on credit, I'll then return with a discussion of o
componenttext:
Welcome, everyone. I'll begin with a review of the third quarter performance highlights. After my overview, Don will follow with his usual overview of our financial performance. Dan will provide an update on credit, I'll then return with a discussion of our near-term outlook and key messages to investors. I want to repeat some key points we made in our September Investor Day that are critical for understanding what is driving this company and our financial performance. 
First, we're in a period of continued economic weakness. It's not going to get back to what we all remembered for years. Economic growth will be slow and choppy. Second is the permanent change in consumer and business behavior. Consumers and businesses are deleveraging, and will be reluctant to releverage. There's a new appreciation for savings and cash accumulation. And there's an intense focus on value and for spending lower absolute amounts. And while convenience has always been important to customers, today, it's more important than ever. First, the impact of increased regulation. This means pressure on revenue, higher compliance costs and an increase in prospective capital requirements.
So to position Huntington to win in this type of environment, we first needed to get our credit issues addressed. We believe the aggressive actions taken last year to identify and resolve credit issues accomplished this objective. The continued credit improvement in the third quarter and our ability to maintain strong reserves, while also reducing provision expense, is evidence of our success on this front. 
Next, we needed to develop and implement a strategic plan that would position Huntington to grow core revenues and win in this type of new environment. Our strategic plan was developed and launched last year and continues to be implemented and will evolve. And while it has many aspects, two are worth noting: First was the decision significant investments to organically grow revenue. This included increasing our cross-sell capabilities, as well as making investments and developing new revenue streams, distribution channels and the talent to manage this expansion. The most recent example was our announcement of a 15-year agreement with Giant Eagle to roll out 103 in-store branches over the next few years. We also, this week, announced the hiring of Jeff Dennes, a nationally-recognized leader in online mobile and payments industry, and Jeff will be our Director of Online and Mobile Services.
Second and in response to the environmental and customer attitude and behavioral changes just mentioned, we adopted our Fair Play banking philosophy discussed last month. One aspect was last month's introduction of 24-hour grace on personal overdraft fees. This is creating significant market buzz. Customers are noticing and responding. We believe that the benefits of accelerated customer acquisition and the revenue we will generate will more than offset the fees given up both voluntarily, as well those that are regulatory driven through Reg E and otherwise. 
The implementation of our strategic initiatives create an earnings dynamic where expense growth precedes related revenue gains. Usually in this situation, earnings growth slows down or plateaus, and some of that is evident in our third quarter performance. Our aggressive handling of credit issues last year is enabling us to reduce provision expense this year, translating to earnings growth. 
Importantly, any plateauing is expected to be short-lived as we're already experiencing increased revenues from our strategic initiatives. This growth is evident in net interest income growth that's reflected strong growth in auto loans in two consecutive quarters now of C&I loan growth. 
Given all of this and what's going on in the environment, you can understand why we're pleased that for three consecutive quarters, we reported higher net income. In sum, the third quarter represented another meaningful step forward in moving Huntington financial performance and for breaking away from some of our competition. 
Now let's begin more detailed discussion, turning to Slide 8. We reported net income of $100.9 million or $0.10 a share, and the performance drivers were more of provision expense and higher net interest income. And we believe these trends will continue. Our pretax, pre-provision income was $265 million, down $5 million or 2% from the second quarter. On one hand, given the revenue and economic environment challenges, this is not unexpected. But we are not satisfied with this performance. The primary driver of our growth in pretax income were the $74 million decline in provision for credit losses, as we continue to see significant credit quality improvement such as an 18% decline in nonaccrual loans and a 7% decrease in net charge-offs, excluding Franklin-related impacts of the second quarter. 
Even though our allowance for credit losses as a percentage of period-end loans declined, as Dan will elaborate, our nonaccrual loan coverage increased to 140% from 120%. And we believe our key credit metrics such as reserve coverage and nonperforming loan and NPA ratios now fall within the top quartile peer performance, while also showing a clear and sustained trend line.
Also contributing growth in pre-tax income was $7.9 million or a 1% increase in full tax equivalent revenue, which was driven by a $24 million or 3% increase in full taxable equivalent net interest income. Our net interest margin was 3.45% down one basis point, and we posted a 1% increase annualized in total average loans and leases, reflecting the auto growth and the C&I growth mentioned earlier. 
Fee income declined $2.5 million or 1%, primarily driven by lower service charges on deposit accounts. Partially offsetting these benefits was a $13.5 million increase in non-interest expense, primarily reflecting the ongoing implementation of our strategic initiatives. 
Turning to Slide 9, all of our period and capital ratios improved. Regulatory Tier 1 and total risk-based ratios are $2.9 billion and $2.2 billion above well-capitalized regulatory thresholds. Our tangible common equity improved eight bps to 6.2%, and our Tier 1 common risk-based capital ratio improved 30 basis points to 7.36%. Lastly, our liquidity position remains strong. We saw 2% annualized core deposit growth for the period end loan-to-deposit ratio of 91%.
As shown on Slide 10, we continue to move forward with our positioning for growth with the implementation of strategic initiatives designed to grow future revenue. And these included increasing the investment in our brand, this was evidenced by higher marketing expenses; by retail and business banking introduction of Fair Play banking philosophy and our launch of 24-Hour Grace. That feature gives our retail customers one business day to cover an account overdraft with no penalty, with no charge. Additionally, our auto finance group continues its expansion eastward by complement an earlier expansion in eastern Pennsylvania which have expanded into five New England states. 
Each of these initiatives are specifically targeted to grow revenue. The appendix and slideshow in all other initiatives since the first quarter of 2009. We have and are very excited -- we are very excited about the cumulative impact and opportunities these represent. 
So let me turn the presentation over to Don to review the details. Don?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Steve. Slide 11 provide a summary of our quarterly earnings trends. Our performance metrics will be discussed later in the presentation so let's move on. Slide 12 is a summary income statement and shows that the $68.6 million increase in pretax
componenttext:
Thanks, Steve. Slide 11 provide a summary of our quarterly earnings trends. Our performance metrics will be discussed later in the presentation so let's move on. 
Slide 12 is a summary income statement and shows that the $68.6 million increase in pretax income reflects the benefit of $74.2 million decline and expense and $10.3 million increase in net interest income, which were partially offset by $13.5 million increase in expenses and a $2.5 million decrease in non-interest income. I'll detail these changes in subsequent slides. 
A point Steve mentioned earlier, this is exactly the dynamic we are expecting. By addressing our credit issues last year, we are seeing improvement in credit costs. This allowed us to fund our strategic initiatives while not net income growth. Further as part the benefits of our strategic initiatives continue to build, our objective is to continue earnings growth once credit costs return to more normal levels.
Turning to Slide 13, we show the trends in our revenues hour pretax pre-provisioned income on the last end of the slide. Revenues of continued throughout the last seven quarters. Revenues for the third quarter up 9% over the third quarter of last year. Our pretax pre-provision earnings are about 11% from the last year despite a 2% decline from previous quarter. This decline was caused by several factors including a drop in of revenues of $10 million. We expect pretax pre-provision levels to remain relatively stable even taking into account the remaining impact of Reg E, our Fair Play banking philosophy and lower expected mortgage banking revenues.
Slide 14 depicts the trends of our net interest income in margin. During the third quarter, our full tax equivalent net interest income increased by $10.4 million, reflecting a one basis point decline in our net interest margin to 3.45% and a $0.9 billion increase to our average earning asset base. The margin change reflects several impacts. First, was a favorable impact of our deposit mix and pricing changes. The mix shift from our time deposits to more transaction-based core deposits, both reduced our cost, but also resulted in a more stable deposit base for us as well. Offsetting this positive impact was a $7.5 million or six basis-point reduction to margin coming from the Franklin-related loans. During the third quarter, we completed the sale of Franklin-related loans involving a reduction to net interest income.
This loss of revenue will be more than offset by the reduction in servicing-related costs incurred for the Franklin-related loans. We would expect Franklin-related expenses to decline by $4 million next quarter due to the sale. Other items impacting the quarter included lower interest income on our interest-rate derivatives. Also the day count negatively impacted the third quarter margin. 
Continuing on to Slide 15, which show a change in our deposit mix over the last five quarters. The shift from 40% of our deposits in time and non-core amount to 29% has improved margin by 22 basis points.
Turning to Slide 16, we showed a 1% growth in total core deposits. This was driven by strong growth in money market accounts as interest-bearing demand deposits declined. 
Slide 17 shows the trends in our loan and lease portfolio. Total commercial loans were down $0.1 billion or 1%. The decline reflected the anticipated decline in commercial real estate balances. The $0.1 billion increase to C&I loans reflected improving customer acquisition, resulting from some of the early benefits of our strategic initiatives, including growth in our equipment finance area. These increases were not impacted by increasing utilization rates as they remained at historic low levels of 42%.
Consumer loans were up $0.3 billion or 2% from the prior quarter. The $0.5 billion increase in average automobile loans and leases reflected record originations of over $1 billion this past quarter. These originations continue to reflect very high credit quality and reasonable returns. 
Slide 18 shows the trends in our noninterest income category. Our non-interest income decreased by $2.5 million from the prior quarter. Our deposit service charges were down by $10 million reflecting the adoption of the changes to Reg E and the early stage impact of our Fair Play banking philosophy. We would expect a similar decline in deposit service charges over the next quarter.
Mortgage banking revenue increased at $6.5 billion, reflecting an 81% risk origination and secondary marketing income on $1.6 billion of originations. This increase was offset by a $7.9 million decrease in MSR hedging income. In the second quarter, the MSR hedging income reflected a change to the underlying prepayment assumptions for the MSR assets, which contribute to a $12.2 million benefit to income last quarter. 
The next slide is a summary of our expense trends. Total expenses were about $13.5 million from the prior quarter. This reflected a $13.4 million increase in personnel costs. This increase was due to a 1.5% increase in staffing levels, attributed to the strategic initiative implemented over the last several quarters, higher production related expenses of $5.6 million and higher pension and 401(k) costs of $3.2 million. 
OREO on foreclosure expenses were up $7.1 million from the second quarter as the prior quarter included a $3.7 million OREO gain in the current quarter and included $2 million Franklin-related OREO loss. We're continuing to manage down our OREO portfolio. 
Marketing costs were also up $3.2 million, attributed to brand advertising campaign. The decline in professional services of $3.7 million reflects the reduction in servicing costs for the Franklin-related loans. Continued reduction in this cost should be reflected in the fourth quarter.
Slide 20 is a summary of our capital trends. The current quarter's net income resulted in an increased to our tangible common equity ratio to 6.2% from 6.12% despite a $1.4 billion increase to our asset base, reflecting even stronger improvement to our Tier 1 capital ratio which increased to 7.36% from 7.06% and our Tier 1 ratio which increased from 12.76% to 12.51%. These increases not only benefited from a capital accretive earning but also from a decrease in the total disallowed deferred tax asset  for regulatory capital purposes, from $191 million at June 30 to $113 million as of September 30. Our first tax asset realization for regulatory capital purposes improved the ratios by about 18 basis points.
Turning to Slide 21, our initial review of the Basel III guidelines would suggest a minimal impact on regulatory capital ratios at less than 10 basis points. This has been in our Tier 1 ratio for the trust preferred securities, which currently adds about 133 basis points to this ratio. 
Related to our TARP repayment plans, our message is basically the same. We recognize that our earnings are returning to more core levels, and that's positive. Yet the economy remains fragile. Also additional clarity is needed from the regulators on the interpretation of the TARP. As we said previously, our objective is to repay when we believe it is prudent to do so. 
Let me turn the presentation over to Dan Neumeyer to review credit trends. Dan?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Don. Slide 22 provides an overview of our credit quality trends. We continue to make very good progress in improving our credit quality metrics, both the nonaccrual loan ratio and the nonperforming asset ratio shows significant improvement in the
componenttext:
Thanks, Don. Slide 22 provides an overview of our credit quality trends. We continue to make very good progress in improving our credit quality metrics, both the nonaccrual loan ratio and the nonperforming asset ratio shows significant improvement in the quarter, the latter aided by the sale of Franklin assets that were moved to health for sale in the second quarter and disposed of in the third quarter. We continue to see continued, meaningful reductions in our non-performers in the coming quarters. Criticized loan level also continued to decline despite unsettled economic conditions. 
The net charge-off ratio fell to 1.98% on an annualized basis, a further reduction from the prior quarter. 90-day loans past due and accruing interests saw a very slight uptick in the quarter, not unexpected given seasonal patterns in consumer behavior. The ACL ratio moved from 3.67% from 3.9%, although coverage ratios on both non-accruals and nonperforming assets continued to show very healthy improvement given significantly lower nonperforming asset levels. The ACL to criticized asset ratio also showed stronger coverage, an indication that we're adequately reserved against emerging problem loans. 
We continue to work to rebalance the portfolio with an emphasis on reducing non-core commercial real estate exposure, while continuing to grow C&I and consumer categories. Indirect auto is originating record volumes with excellent credit quality metrics. 
Slide 23 provides a graphic presentation of a nonaccrual loan and nonperforming assets trends on the left side of the slide and the nonaccrual loan inflow on the right side. The overall trend in nonaccrual loans and nonperforming assets continues to be very positive, and exhibits very meaningful improvement in the last four quarters.
Nonaccrual inflows did experience an increase in the quarter, reflecting a continued fragile economy. Several larger credits contributed much of the increase and were placed on nonaccrual in line with our continued conservative posture of early recognition and resolution of emerging problem loans. 30% of our total commercial loans are nonaccrual remain current on principal and interest. 
Turning to Slide 24, we can review the entire nonperforming asset flow analysis. As mentioned, we did see an increase in new NPAs in the third quarter, reflecting continued economic stress and the uneven nature of the commercial portfolio recovery. However, we also saw an increase in loans returning to accruing status and an increase in payments. These factors, along with asset sales, contributed to a 30% reduction in NPAs for the quarter, the most significant reduction in some time. 
Slide 25 continues our disclosure on the level of criticized commercial loans. Criticized commercial loans fell 11% for the second consecutive quarter, showing sustained momentum in the level of problem loan resolution. The fragility of the economic environment remains apparent as we continued to see an inflow of new watchlist loans. However, we also continue to see a healthy level of loans moving back to the past category by risk rating upgrades and an increase in the level of pay downs on these criticized loans. It's our expectation that despite like challenging outlook, we'll continue to make good progress in reducing our overall level of criticized loans in the coming quarters.
Reflecting the unevenness of the recovery, our total commercial loan, 30-day delinquencies increased to 1.08% from 0.95% at the end of the second quarter. Almost all of these loans are managed of our Special Assets Department and receive the highest level of scrutiny and attention. 90 days past dues remain at zero for the fourth consecutive quarter, again, reflecting our aggressive treatment of developing problem loans. 
Slide 27 demonstrates the improved credit quality associated with the consumer portfolios. Overall, consumer delinquencies in the 30-day category continued to an exhibit improving trend. 
Residential mortgage and auto continue to show improvement from the prior quarter, while home equity loans exhibit a small increase. In the 90-day category, auto and home equity held fairly steady from the prior quarter while residential delinquencies demonstrated an increase. Although some seasonal upticks are anticipated, we continue to manage our delinquency levels very closely and expect the overall positive trend to continue. 
Delinquency measures in all consumer categories were better than at 9/30, one year ago. Our consumer portfolio consists primarily of loans within our footprint and is relationship-based. We continued to originate high quality assets with high FICO scores and reasonable loan-to-value.
Turning to Slide 28, commercial net charge-offs continued to show an improving trend following 10% from the prior quarter. Lower levels of NPAs showed continued declines in commercial charge-offs. Consumer loan charge-offs were flat in dollar terms but as a percentage of loans spelled due to additional loan growth primarily in auto. While high unemployment rates and economic malaise continued to present challenges in the consumer portfolio, the relationship nature our portfolio, coupled with early intervention and managing delinquencies, should allow us to exhibit continued positive momentum in the consumer book.
Turning to Slide 29, the loan-loss provision for the third quarter of $119 million with less than charge-offs of $184 million. This resulted in ACL-to-loans of 3.67, down from 3.9 at June 30. Importantly, the coverage ratio of ACL to NALs increased significantly from 120% at June 30th to 140% at September 30. Also the coverage ratio relative to criticized assets continued to increase an overall credit quality which remains much improved. We believe this level of coverage is very healthy and quite strong relative to our peer group. We also believe that it is appropriate given the difficult economic environment that remain before us. 
Overall, we remain very pleased with our progress in the credit front and all of our portfolios. We are cognizant of the challenges that remain before us and are confident in our ability to navigate through them while demonstrating continued improvement in our credit metrics. Let me turn the presentation back to Steve.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd like to use Slide 30 to recap the current thinking regarding near-term expectations. The CRE covered by these expectations is beyond the fourth quarter but to some extent determined by what happens in the economy. So here's our thinking -- it's going
componenttext:
I'd like to use Slide 30 to recap the current thinking regarding near-term expectations. The CRE covered by these expectations is beyond the fourth quarter but to some extent determined by what happens in the economy. So here's our thinking -- it's going to remain generally weak, no meaningful change is expected. Confidence continues to be a challenge at very low levels. We're not anticipating, however, a double-dip recession. We do believe, however, that any recovery is getting pushed further and further out. So the key drivers of net income growth are expected to be from net interest income and lower provision for credit losses, reflecting our expectation for continued improvement in our key credit metrics, including adoptions in nonperforming assets at lower charge-offs, which we saw in the third quarter. 
Again, pretax pre-provision earnings will likely remain comparable to the 2010 year-to-date performance, with similar dynamics as that seen in the third quarter performance. We anticipate modest loan growth, driven by continued strong growth in autos and some growth in the C&I loans, partially offset by continued declines in commercial real estate loans. We still do not anticipate much, if any growth, to home equity loans. Residential mortgage refinancing activity will likely remain above historical trends due to continued low interest rates, but since most of our loans originated are fixed-rate which we sell, we're not likely to see much growth, if any, in this category. 
We continue to expect growth in demand deposit, and savings accounts, and although we may choose to manage that growth differently, if we continue to see limited reinvestment options. Fee income growth we expect will be mixed. We anticipate improvements in our strategic initiatives, as they gain further traction. Yet much of the growth near-term may be mitigated by lower mortgage banking income and declines in service charges on deposits. 
Manager's expense is expected to remain relatively stable with third quarter performance, with growth from strategic initiatives mitigated by lower credit-related and to some extent some lower marketing expenses. Taking all of this together, we anticipate continued modest growth in net income. 
On Slide 31, in closing, I want to remind all of our investors and customers of several key messages, our balance sheet is strong and our capital levels are sufficient and getting stronger with each passing profitable quarter. Our substantially improved credit quality performance positions us to obtain top quartile performance. Our strategic initiatives continue to gain traction, and while the environment is challenging, everyday we are making progress. We are clearly on the move. We are growing and getting stronger. So thank you for your interest in Huntington. 
Operator, we'll now take questions.[Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from the line of Ken Zerbe from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: In terms of the initiatives, I understand it are doing a lot to grow revenue, and I think that's great. But can you just talk a little bit about the cautiousness of that -- and I did hear your comments that you're trying -- a lot of the expenses are being
componenttext: In terms of the initiatives, I understand it are doing a lot to grow revenue, and I think that's great. But can you just talk a little bit about the cautiousness of that -- and I did hear your comments that you're trying -- a lot of the expenses are being offset currently. But maybe once these initiatives get up and running, how much of those additional incremental expense build, gets pulled out of earnings or does it just remain in earnings going forward?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, this is Don. As far as the initiative, many of them have a six- to nine-month type of payback period as far as from the investments and the people. So the challenge we've had is that we've been compounding many of these on top of one another. So we d
componenttext: Ken, this is Don. As far as the initiative, many of them have a six- to nine-month type of payback period as far as from the investments and the people. So the challenge we've had is that we've been compounding many of these on top of one another. So we did see some expense growth this past quarter that was an outlier compared to the revenue growth. But I'd say that we are expecting the fee to return there. That the expense increases this past quarter reflected not only some of the initiatives but also the benefit from some higher levels of mortgage production, which resulted in higher incentive costs for us as well. So each one of these will have a different defined payback period. That's just a general guideline.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the other question I have was on the DTA for the disallowed DTA for Reg capital. To rough amounts I get something like 66 basis points is still left to be recognized that there may be off a couple of points. But can you talk about the timing of w
componenttext: And then the other question I have was on the DTA for the disallowed DTA for Reg capital. To rough amounts I get something like 66 basis points is still left to be recognized that there may be off a couple of points. But can you talk about the timing of when you do expect to ultimately receive all of the benefit from your DTA? And the other thing is do regulators view that as actually legitimate capital when they think about you guys repaying TARP?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ken, as far as the DTA, we have about $113 million left. And so it's probably a little different than the 68-basis-point-type of calculation. I think on roughly $43 billion in risk-weighted assets that we would expect that to be realized throughout the ne
componenttext: Ken, as far as the DTA, we have about $113 million left. And so it's probably a little different than the 68-basis-point-type of calculation. I think on roughly $43 billion in risk-weighted assets that we would expect that to be realized throughout the next several quarters up through 2011. So I think that we will see that come back. As far as how the regulators would read that in connection with any TARP repayment, it is recognized for GAAP purposes, and for regulatory GAAP purposes. I don't know that there'll be any differentiation as far as that type of asset. I think even with new Basel III requirements, take a look at what level of DTA and certain other more intangible assets are compared to total Tier 1 Capital, and we'd be below that threshold as well.

componenttext: There were several large transactions, but in terms of a theme, no. We had one real estate transaction, we had a metal fabricator, we had one large building supply provider. So I think that goes along with the general theme of what we've been seeing in the economy. Those are troubled areas and very lumpy. And I think in this quarter it just happened we have three larger ones that was quite atypical, actually.

componenttext: These have obviously been targeted areas for us for 18 months or longer in terms of getting our arms around those and so forth. So on that instance, we had three loans totaling about $100 million, but overall, we have been looking very hard at commercial real estate and have taken significant credit marks on the portfolio, well-reserved and, again, homebuilder supply and manufacturing segments, particularly auto-related, have been in our target list. So those have been quickly identified and dealt with for about the last 18 months.

componenttext: Final question for Don, there was a rundown in interest bearing DDA in the quarter. Do you sense that any of that was related maybe as a precursor to a pickup in C&I loan demand? Has there been any change on that front in terms of utilization rate or anything like that?

componenttext: I think more of that was actually related to the expiration activity of TAGP for us. That expired for us as of June 30. We did see an increase in some of our suite balances and other short-term borrowings. We saw an increase there of about $700 million. So what we may have normally come in that interest bearing deposits over the last couple of quarters was coming through that suite product.

componenttext: This is actually Elena Kim sitting in for Heather Wolf. I noticed that at the end of period, investment securities balance increased significantly but the yield did not. So is it safe to assume that you're reinvesting in the same duration, similar assets?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: We are investing in very similar type of assets that most of the growth this past quarter came in at agency mortgage-backed and agency CMOs. So it's a very short-term duration, two to three-year type of levels. So we're intentionally keeping that fairly s
componenttext: We are investing in very similar type of assets that most of the growth this past quarter came in at agency mortgage-backed and agency CMOs. So it's a very short-term duration, two to three-year type of levels. So we're intentionally keeping that fairly short. We don't think it's prudent to be extending that duration in this low rate environment.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good job on the C&I and auto loan growth. But I just had a quick question on the new yields that you're putting on to your balance sheet. I noticed that the overall yield for those two portfolios went down as volumes went up. So want to know what sort of
componenttext: Good job on the C&I and auto loan growth. But I just had a quick question on the new yields that you're putting on to your balance sheet. I noticed that the overall yield for those two portfolios went down as volumes went up. So want to know what sort of the reinvestment risk is for those two buckets.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As far as the growth in direct auto, the yield came down this past quarter was mainly attributed to the fact that we had an adjusted in the second quarter related to the amortization of certain fee income categories there. And that had a $3 million or $4
componenttext: As far as the growth in direct auto, the yield came down this past quarter was mainly attributed to the fact that we had an adjusted in the second quarter related to the amortization of certain fee income categories there. And that had a $3 million or $4 million lift, which artificially increased the yield compared to previous quarters for that second quarter. As far as the new yields going on the books for indirect auto, it's another 5% to 5.5% average yield for that category. And as you know, we have very strong growth there with over $1 billion of originations. So we're still very pleased with the credit quality and also with the absolute level return for that asset class. As far as the commercial growth, we are seeing some nice growth and some fairly lower-risk categories compared to historic portfolios. And so I'd say that the average spreads are fairly consistent there with the new yields for new originations. But Dan, have you seen anything from your side as far as the differences -- as far as the type of loans?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think we have seen a little bit more in the large corporate area, where we're concentrating on local, large corporate accounts where we have full cross sell opportunities. And given the high-quality there, some of the yields maybe our little bit lower.
componenttext: I think we have seen a little bit more in the large corporate area, where we're concentrating on local, large corporate accounts where we have full cross sell opportunities. And given the high-quality there, some of the yields maybe our little bit lower. Also in our equipment finance area in terms of the new business, priorities are kind of more upmarket. So very high-quality, but would also result in slightly lower yields.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: One last question in terms of funding. I know that you guys had mentioned earlier in the call that you increased your short-term borrowings significantly, and you also saw a slight uptick in brokered CDs. Can you kind of give some color in terms of how yo
componenttext: One last question in terms of funding. I know that you guys had mentioned earlier in the call that you increased your short-term borrowings significantly, and you also saw a slight uptick in brokered CDs. Can you kind of give some color in terms of how you describe your funding?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: As you mentioned, as far as the earlier comments on the short term borrowings, that really relates to our customer suite of product. As the TAGP expired, we no longer provided FDIC insurance for those interest-bearing checking accounts. And so we did see
componenttext: As you mentioned, as far as the earlier comments on the short term borrowings, that really relates to our customer suite of product. As the TAGP expired, we no longer provided FDIC insurance for those interest-bearing checking accounts. And so we did see more growth in that suite of product than we would have historically seen in that interest-bearing checking. As far as broker deposits, we did access the market a little bit this past quarter that we saw some fairly low rates as far as 18-month type of CDs and did book a little bit there. But not much of any size that we have historically for the last four quarters prior that, allowing that book to just go ahead and mature. But we think it's appropriate to just continue to try to access that market occasionally just to test the waters, so to speak.

componenttext: Just getting back to the Fair Play banking philosophy, are there certain things that you are looking at that you're going to share with us over the coming quarters and years to make sure that, that strategy was a success, household growth, core deposit growth, et cetera? So we on the side of the table could also make our opinion whether that was the right move?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Terry, this is Mary. I think, yes, the answer is we will be looking at other opportunities to demonstrate to customers and future customers that we are trying to be more fair and do things right. And there'll be other things that we do. So the next thing
componenttext: Terry, this is Mary. I think, yes, the answer is we will be looking at other opportunities to demonstrate to customers and future customers that we are trying to be more fair and do things right. And there'll be other things that we do. So the next thing we're looking at is our checking account lineup, consumer checking. And so you'll probably hear about that one next. And so far, we're very happy with what we've done with 24-hour Grace, which was one of the things we've talked about at the Investor Day in September. And those numbers look right on track as far as what we said we'd have with fee gives up for Reg E, other overdraft and 24-hour Grace. And we're thrilled with what customers are saying about it and the number of customers that are coming to us because of this account feature.

componenttext: Just a second question, looking at the $609 million of C&I originations, up almost double from last quarter, can you just talk about -- and it may be in the presentation so I apologize, just geography, industry and talk a little bit about what was behind that growth?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Dan. I would say it is very broad-based. I wouldn't say it's limited to any particular geography within our footprint. It is middle market. It's business banking. It's large corporate equipment finance. I think we've seen very equal representation
componenttext: This is Dan. I would say it is very broad-based. I wouldn't say it's limited to any particular geography within our footprint. It is middle market. It's business banking. It's large corporate equipment finance. I think we've seen very equal representation from all areas. And obviously, our focus is on generating high quality assets right now. And I think we are benefiting from being able to move some market share in a low-growth economy. So I'm real pleased with the breakdown of the types of additions threatening the portfolio.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And looking at the pipeline, would you expect that number to grow in the fourth quarter?
componenttext: And looking at the pipeline, would you expect that number to grow in the fourth quarter?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our pipeline is very strong. I think what we're seeing is not atypical from what others are seeing is that the people are requesting credit and getting approved for credit. What we're not seeing as much of this is the line utilization or the drawdowns for
componenttext: Our pipeline is very strong. I think what we're seeing is not atypical from what others are seeing is that the people are requesting credit and getting approved for credit. What we're not seeing as much of this is the line utilization or the drawdowns for capital investments. So pipeline, very strong. In fact that I think it may be at a high point right now. So we're very encouraged by that.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Long from Raymond James.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Long from Raymond James.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions, the first one for Dan and a bit of a follow up to Tony's question, looking at Slide 24 with the inflow to nonperforming assets. You talked about the -- there were few larger currents there that contributed to that. Does that same commentary
componenttext: Two questions, the first one for Dan and a bit of a follow up to Tony's question, looking at Slide 24 with the inflow to nonperforming assets. You talked about the -- there were few larger currents there that contributed to that. Does that same commentary also go for Slide 25 when we're looking at the criticized loan flow and there seem to be a pretty good increase in the additions there? Or was that the same large credits that we should be thinking about?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your first question on the inflows, I do want to stress that, again, we're pretty aggressive when we put loans on nonaccrual. One of the large new NPAs is current and principal and interest. So we think we're taking a very aggressive and proactive posture
componenttext: Your first question on the inflows, I do want to stress that, again, we're pretty aggressive when we put loans on nonaccrual. One of the large new NPAs is current and principal and interest. So we think we're taking a very aggressive and proactive posture in placing those on nonaccrual. We certainly aren't waiting until there are no options left on those credits. In terms of the criticized asset flow, that was fairly broad-based. We saw actually more in terms of dollars in the C&I world and in business banking and actually less in commercial real estate. And when you look at the inflows, it is very diversified, again, amongst geographies. Given this economy, there are a lot of undercapitalized companies that are still struggling. Many have made great advances in cutting their cost structure and are surviving. Others are struggling a bit. So I think it's -- given the kind of a slowdown that we've seen in the last quarter, which began with kind of the European disruption and the effects of that, we have seen a lagged effect on that slow down and I think an increase in the third quarter. We're not necessarily anticipating that same level of inflow in the fourth quarter, but it's kind of too early to tell.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: A second question for Steve. Steve, from one of your concluding slides on your expectations, you talked about managing demand deposit based on your opportunities to reinvest that. How do you manage that with your initiative to really take share in with yo
componenttext: A second question for Steve. Steve, from one of your concluding slides on your expectations, you talked about managing demand deposit based on your opportunities to reinvest that. How do you manage that with your initiative to really take share in with your whole Fair Play banking initiative?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we think we have pricing levers on both time and money market. And as we're growing core household, give us some pricing flexibility. We're very focused on core households and cross-sell ratios. And as we look at our deposit book and the rate enviro
componenttext: Well, we think we have pricing levers on both time and money market. And as we're growing core household, give us some pricing flexibility. We're very focused on core households and cross-sell ratios. And as we look at our deposit book and the rate environment, the competitive dynamics in the Midwest have changed. They've abated substantially over the last couple of years. We think we have some opportunity there over time.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: I don't know if we disclose out term rate for 30-day delinquency. And what we talked about historically though is the level of NPAs that we have are still currently performing, which is roughly 30% of the commercial nonperforming. But I don't know if we've talked about that, that you're aware of Jay?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then the other issue is -- I mean, you guys have some pretty decent loan growths relative to your peer group, but there was the Fed, I think, last month reported that credit is easing, which is a good thing for the economy. But I'm just wondering, are
componenttext: And then the other issue is -- I mean, you guys have some pretty decent loan growths relative to your peer group, but there was the Fed, I think, last month reported that credit is easing, which is a good thing for the economy. But I'm just wondering, are you easing some of your underwriting standards or are you just seeing better credits coming in the door?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say we are not easing our credit standards at all. We are certainly taking into account what businesses have been going through and those indicating a turnaround, we are taking that into full account and we may not see the string of historical pro
componenttext: I would say we are not easing our credit standards at all. We are certainly taking into account what businesses have been going through and those indicating a turnaround, we are taking that into full account and we may not see the string of historical profitability that we normally would have. We may have to rely on some turnaround stories. But we underwrite that very well and look at industry business models, management capabilities, et cetera to do that. We have not eased our standards. There's certainly been some competitive pressure with respect to price because everyone is going after that same quality customer. But in terms of our underwriting, I feel real good about what we're originating.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: When you say turnaround string, can you elaborate on that a little bit?
componenttext: When you say turnaround string, can you elaborate on that a little bit?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. Obviously beginning this last cycle, there's probably in some cases, a majority of certain industries where customers would have been losing money. And normally, when you're looking at approving credit, you like to see a nice string of consistent ea
componenttext: Sure. Obviously beginning this last cycle, there's probably in some cases, a majority of certain industries where customers would have been losing money. And normally, when you're looking at approving credit, you like to see a nice string of consistent earnings and debt service coverage. Where in a turnaround situation, once someone has come out of it, they're generating new contracts or they're cutting costs. You have to analyze a shorter earnings history and track record than we might normally do. And that's what we're spending a lot of time on in trying to help businesses that have credit needs.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

componenttext: In the fourth quarter, we should see a $4 million reduction for the total Franklin-related expenses and that should be permanent. That's essentially the servicing related costs and other costs associated with the Franklin assets that were sold. So those should be zero going forward.

componenttext: Massachusetts is still very early so there wouldn't be much of an impact there at all in the third quarter and very little impact as far as Eastern Pennsylvania. So we think those are our opportunities for us, prospectively.

componenttext: I don't know that we have any specific area pricing. But I'd say that our pricing models are fairly consistent across the entire footprint. Again, they focus on very high FICO score originations and very low expected credit costs.

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a couple of questions, nobody's really asked about acquisition activity. I want to get your, sort of an update, Steve, on your thoughts. We seen a couple of deals happen in small banks, you seem to be a little aggressive about trying to pick partners
componenttext: Just a couple of questions, nobody's really asked about acquisition activity. I want to get your, sort of an update, Steve, on your thoughts. We seen a couple of deals happen in small banks, you seem to be a little aggressive about trying to pick partners so your view there would be helpful. And also I noticed in Jay's and Todd's extensive slide deck on Page 153 that your ratings from Moody's and Fitch are about a year old. Any update on meeting with the rating agencies on what's going on there?

headline: Huntington Bancshares Inc., Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 21, 2010
componenttextpreview: The acquisition front first -- there's more activity for sure. But our stance on this hasn't changed. We're looking to drive our core number five and sort our -- or the way we think about things, and its reflective on one of the pages is Acquisition. And
componenttext: The acquisition front first -- there's more activity for sure. But our stance on this hasn't changed. We're looking to drive our core number five and sort our -- or the way we think about things, and its reflective on one of the pages is Acquisition. And os something interesting is available, then we'd pursue it. There's a lot of -- from what we've seen so far, nothing is compelling.

componenttextpreview: As far as the rating agencies, they still haven't acknowledge that they tend to be incremental in their approach as far us changing rating. But we did have S&P take us from a negative outlook to a positive outlook. And so we hope that, that's a good sign
componenttext: As far as the rating agencies, they still haven't acknowledge that they tend to be incremental in their approach as far us changing rating. But we did have S&P take us from a negative outlook to a positive outlook. And so we hope that, that's a good sign for us going forward as it relates to their rating and we continue to talk to all three of our rating agencies that we report in to. And hopefully, we'll start to see some reaction over time, but no commitments at this point.
